questions.text: Which of the following is considered a type of mechanical ventilation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Plenum

Explanation:

Types of Ventilation

Natural 

Mechanical

1. Wind:

  • Perflation (Option B): wind blows through a room
  • Aspiration: wind bypasses and exerts a suction
  • Cross-ventilation.

2. Diffusion (Option C): Air passes through small openings

3. Temperature Inequality (Option D): Air movement from high to low density due to temperature difference.

1. Exhaust: air is extracted outside by exhaust fans

2. Plenum (Option A ): fresh air blown inside by centrifugal fans

3. Balanced: Combination of exhaust and plenum

4. Air conditioning: control of all air factors affecting physical and chemical conditions of the atmosphere

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He reports severe ankle pain and is unable to bear weight. X-rays reveal a fracture in the neck of the talus, and is shown below. Based on Hawkin's classification, which type of fracture does this represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Type III

 

Explanation:

The X-ray indicates a displaced fracture of the neck of the talus, accompanied by dislocation of the body of the talus from both the ankle and subtalar joints, pointing towards a diagnosis of Hawkins Type III fracture.

Talus Fracture:

  • M/c Site: Talar Neck
  • Mechanism of Injury: Hyperdorsiflexion of the ankle

  • M/c Cause: RTA> Fall from heights
  • Also called aviator fracture:
    • When an aircraft strikes the ground at an angle, the foot rests on the rudder bar.
    • On impact, the talus is pressed into the instep, just in front of the heel.
    • Talus absorbs most of the force and becomes the site of the fracture.
  • Hawkin’s Classification:

 

Type I (Option A)

Undisplaced vertical fracture neck of talus

Type II (Option B)

Displaced fracture neck + Subluxation or dislocation of subtalar joint

Type III (Option C)

Displaced fracture neck + Dislocation of the body of the talus from both ankle and subtalar joints

Type IV (Option D)

Displaced fracture neck + Dislocation of the head and body of the talus from subtalar/ankle/talonavicular joints

 

 

  • Treatment:

 

Undisplaced Fracture

Displaced Fracture
  • Conservative treatment
  • Below-knee plaster cast
  • For 8-10 weeks
  • Closed reduction by traction in plantar flexion and a plaster cast is put in equinus.
  • If it fails, ORIF with lag screws is done.
  • Sometimes Herbert bone screw is used:
    • Headless compression screw
    • Generally not removed

 

  • Complication:
    • Avascular necrosis (AVN):
      • Hawkins I: 0% to 13% AVN
      • Hawkins II: 20% to 50% AVN
      • Hawkins III: 20% to 100% AVN
      • Hawkins IV: 70% to 100% AVN
    • Delayed union and nonunion
    • Malunion
    • Osteoarthritis of the ankle

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department after an accidental chemical exposure to his eyes while working in a lab. He reports immediate burning and decreased vision. Upon examination, there is corneal epithelial loss and conjunctival swelling. What is the most appropriate immediate management step?

choices.text: Necrotic tissue removal and administer topical antibiotics
Immediate irrigation with water or saline for 20-30 minutes

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Immediate irrigation with water or saline for 20-30 minutes

 

Explanation:

The above clinical case is suggestive of chemical injury. Irrigation with water or saline is the priority to dilute and remove the chemical, minimizing damage.

Management of Chemical Injury

  • Immediate irrigation: Copious water/saline for 20–30 min or until pH normal; double eversion of lids.
  • Debridement: Removal of dead conjunctiva/corneal epithelium with cotton swab (Option A).
  • Antibiotics: To prevent secondary infection (Option A).
  • Cycloplegics: For ciliary muscle relaxation and pain relief.Steroids: Only for initial 7 days (reduce inflammation but impair healing) (Option B).
  • Vitamin C (Ascorbic acid): 10% eye drops 2-hourly to promote collagen synthesis.
  • Collagenase inhibitors: Citrate 10% drops, tetracycline, acetylcysteine 10%.
  • Early surgical options: Tenon advancement, limbal cell transplant, amniotic membrane graft.
  • Late surgical options: Symblepharon release with conjunctival/mucous graft, keratoplasty (Option D). if corneal opacity.

Complications: Secondary glaucoma, limbal stem cell deficiency, pseudopterygium, corneal opacity

questions.text: In a histopathological examination of a lung biopsy from a patient with suspected sarcoidosis, which of the following microscopic features would be most characteristic and supportive of the diagnosis?

choices.text: Macrophages with abundant cytoplasm containing dusty brown pigment
Non-necrotizing granulomas with asteroid bodies and Schaumann bodies

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Non-necrotizing granulomas with asteroid bodies and Schaumann bodies

 

Explanation:

  • Sarcoidosis is characterised by non-necrotizing granulomas containing asteroid bodies (stellate-shaped structures) and Schaumann bodies (calcium and protein inclusions).
  • Composition of Schaumann bodies: Calcium
  • Non-caseating granulomas are common, but caseating granulomas can also be seen rarely.
  • Caseating granulomas are mainly indicative of necrotising TB. (Option C ruled out)
  • Macrophages with abundant cytoplasm containing dusty brown pigment is a normal finding seen after inhalation of dust particles. (Option A ruled out)
  • Curschmann spirals and Charcot-Leyden crystals are associated with Asthma (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of bilateral cataracts, short stature, premature greying and loss of hair, and skin changes. He also reports joint stiffness and pain, as well as type 2 diabetes mellitus. On examination, the patient appears older than his stated age, with characteristic "bird-like" facies and a high-pitched voice. Which of the following conditions is most likely to be associated with his presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Werner syndrome

Explanation:

The clinical presentation points towards Werner syndrome, also known as Adult Progeria Syndrome, an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by premature ageing features that typically manifest in adulthood. It is associated with a DNA helicase defect.

Hutchinson-Gilford Syndrome (Option A): It is a rare genetic progeroid syndrome characterized by severe premature ageing features that begin in childhood. It is a Laminopathy due to a Lamin-A (LMNA) gene mutation.

Wermer Syndrome (Option C): Wermer Syndrome is for as multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1).

Cockayne Syndrome (Option D): It is also a rare autosomal recessive progeroid syndrome. However, it typically presents in childhood. ERCC gene defect.

questions.text: A 60 y/o male presents with fever, cough, and foul-smelling sputum. A chest X-ray reveals a localized opacity in the apical lower lobe. Sputum culture shows the presence of anaerobic bacteria. Which of the following is the most likely cause?

choices.text: Bronchial obstruction due to lung cancer

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A)Aspiration of oropharyngeal secretions

Explanation:

The X-ray shows a lung abscess. Aspiration is the most common cause of lung abscesses, particularly in the apical lower lobe, and is frequently associated with anaerobic bacteria from the oral cavity.

 

Lung Abscess Localized suppuration in the lung is characterized by tissue necrosis

 

Aetiology:

  • Infectious: Pneumonia due to Streptococcus, Pneumococcus, Haemophilus, Staphylococcus, anaerobic bacteria, etc.
  • Chronic upper respiratory infections (e.g., sinusitis, tonsillitis, dental infections).
  • Mechanical: Bronchial obstruction due to tumours or foreign bodies.
  • Other Causes: Septicaemia and aspiration, commonly lead to lung abscess in the apical lower lobe.

Sites of Infection:

  • Apical Lower Lobe: Most frequently involved in aspiration-related lung abscesses.
  • Posterior Segments: Can be affected due to gravity when aspiration occurs.
  • Upper Lobes: May be involved in cases of tuberculosis or certain types of pneumonia.

 

Routes of Infection:

  • Aspiration: Inhalation of oropharyngeal or gastrointestinal secretions, often leading to anaerobic infections from the oral cavity.
  • Hematogenous Spread: From e.g., endocarditis or septicemia
  • Direct Extension: Localized infections in adjacent structures (e.g., pneumonia, empyema) can extend into lung tissue.

 

 

Hematogenous spread from endocarditis (Option B): While it can cause lung abscesses, it is less common than aspiration in the context of anaerobic infections and would typically present with multiple abscesses rather than a localized opacity.

Direct extension from pneumonia (Option C) can cause lung abscesses, but in this case, the specific presence of anaerobic bacteria and the apical location suggest aspiration as the more likely cause.

Bronchial obstruction due to lung cancer (Option D) is a possible cause of infection and abscess formation, but the presence of anaerobic bacteria and the patient's age make aspiration a more plausible cause, especially in the context of a localized opacity in the lung.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with no medical comorbidities complaints of involuntary leakage of urine primarily when she coughs or sneezes. She has tried Kegel exercises, lifestyle modifications, such as avoiding caffeine, and pessary but these have not significantly improved her symptoms. What would be the most appropriate next step in the management of her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Colposuspension surgery

Explanation:

In this scenario, all the conservative and less invasive measures have failed. Hence, the next best step in management is colposuspension surgery.

Treatment of urinary incontinence:

Type of urinary Incontinence

Stress urinary Incontinence

Urgency urinary Incontinence

Overflow Incontinence

Step 1
  • Lifestyle
  • Weight loss in obese individuals
  • Reduce fluid and caffeine intake
  • Avoiding bladder irritants (e.g., caffeine, alcohol, carbonated drinks)
  • Restrict intake of fluid to 1 liter/day

If non-obstructive pathology

  • Continuous catheter drainage
  • Intermittent self-catheterization

Step 2
  • Pelvic floor muscle training( Kegel exercises)
  • Biofeedback therapy
  • Scheduled Voiding
  • Bladder retraining
  • Scheduled voiding

If obstructive pathology

  • Alpha-blockers (tamsulosin for bladder outlet obstruction)
  • Urethroplasty for urethral strictures

Step 3

Medical Treatment

  • Estrogen
  • Sympathomimetic drugs (α-adrenergic) Imipramine

Medical Treatment

  • Anticholinergics:
  1. Oxybutynin
  2. Tolterodine
  3. Fesoterodine fumarate
  4. Darifenacin
  • Beta -3 adrenergic agonist (Mirabegron* )
  • Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., imipramine)
  

Step 4

Devices

  • Pessary
  • Urethral Inserts

Neuromodulation

  • Sacral nerve stimulation
  • Peripheral tibial nerve stimulation

Intradetrusor botulinum toxin A injection

 

  

Step 5

Surgical Treatment

  • Colposuspension
  • Midurethral tape

Tension-free vaginal tape (TVT)

Transobturator tape (TOT)

  • Microslings
  • Bladder neck suspension
  • Bulking agents injection
  • Others

Marshall-Marchetti-Krantz (MMK)

Paravaginal repair

Surgical Treatment

  • Cystoplasty (to increase bladder capacity)
  • Urinary diversion procedures (eg. ileal conduit)
  
  • Note: Mirabegron contraindicated in severe uncontrolled hypertension systolic blood pressure ≥180 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure ≤ 110 mm Hg, or both
  • Mirabegron is better tolerated than antimuscarinics in older patients and can be considered as an alternative to antimuscarinics for elderly patients.

questions.text:
A mother brings her apparently normal 20-day-old newborn to the pediatric clinic with a complaint of milk coming through the nasal passages of the baby during feeding. Upon examination, you find the following:
 



 

This condition is due to the failure of which of the following processes during embryonic development?

choices.text: Fusion of the maxillary and medial nasal processes
Formation of the lateral palatine processes

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fusion of the palatal shelves.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Cleft palate occurs when the palatal shelves fail to elevate and fuse properly during embryonic development, typically between the 6th and 9th weeks of gestation.
  • This results in a gap in the palate, allowing communication between the oral and nasal cavities, as evidenced by milk coming through the nasal passages during feeding.

Cleft palate:

Defective fusion of the various components of the palate gives rise to clefts in the palate.

 

Complete cleft palate:

  • Bilateral complete cleft (A): Failure of fusion of both palatine processes of maxilla with premaxilla. A y-shaped cleft will be present between primary and secondary palate and between the two halves of secondary palate. It presents as a bilateral cleft of the upper lip also.
  • Unilateral complete cleft (B): Nonfusion of one side palatine process of maxilla with premaxilla. It presents as a unilateral cleft of the upper lip.

 

Incomplete cleft palate:

  • Cleft of hard and soft palate( C): Cleft limited to hard palate.
  • Cleft of soft palate (D): Cleft limited to hard palate.
  • Bifid uvula (E): Cleft limited to uvula.

 

Fusion of the maxillary and medial nasal processes (Option A): This contributes to formation of the upper lip and primary palate. Its failure leads to cleft lip, not cleft palate.

Formation of the lateral palatine processes (Option B): While formation is important, fusion failure (not formation) is responsible for the defect in this case.

Formation of the primary palate (Option D): The primary palate forms the region anterior to the incisive foramen; its failure causes anterior clefting, not posterior palatal clefts.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for pregnancy termination under the eugenic grounds of the MTP Act?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Exposure to teratogenic drugs

 

Explanation:

 

Indications for MTP

Therapeutic

(Options A and B ruled out)

Pregnancy that endangers the woman's life or may cause severe physical/mental injury (e.g., cardiac disease, hypertension, epilepsy, intractable hyperemesis gravidarum, breast/ cervical cancer).

Eugenic

(Option C)

Risk of serious physical or mental abnormalities in the fetus (e.g., exposure to teratogenic drugs, infections like rubella, structural abnormalities like anencephaly).

Socio-economic

Unplanned pregnancies in low socio-economic conditions or failure of contraception.

Humanitarian

(Option D ruled out)

Pregnancy resulting from rape.

 

Timing for MTP:

  • Up to 12 weeks: One doctor’s opinion is required.
  • 12 to 20 weeks: Consent of two doctors is needed.
  • Beyond 20 weeks: Only allowed on therapeutic grounds to save the woman’s life (one doctor’s decision).
  • Emergency cases: Any registered doctor can terminate if necessary to save the woman's life.

questions.text: A 45 y/o male undergoes abdominal surgery and requires fluid replacement. The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease. Which of the following fluids is most appropriate for maintenance during surgery to avoid the risk of hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ringer's Lactate

 

Explanation:

  • Ringer's Lactate is often preferred because it contains a buffer (lactate) that helps to mitigate the risk of acidosis.
  • It is isotonic and provides electrolytes in a more balanced way, making it a suitable option for patients with CKD.

 

Ringer's Lactate (Balanced Crystalloid)

  • Usage: Maintenance fluid during surgery.
  • Advantage: Prevents hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, unlike normal saline.
  • Excretion:
    • Rapid elimination due to suppression of ADH secretion, promoting diuresis.

  • Buffer: Lactate metabolised to bicarbonate, maintaining or slightly increasing HCO3− levels, hence preventing acidosis.

 

½ NS (0.45% NaCl, Hypotonic Saline)

  • Usage: Maintenance fluid in the postoperative period along with 4% dextrose.
  • Risk: To minimize the risk of hyponatremia, excessive use of hypotonic solutions, particularly in the postoperative phase, is discouraged.

3% NS (3% NaCl, Hypertonic Saline)

  • Usage: Treatment of symptomatic hyponatremia and cerebral oedema.
  • Mechanism: Draws water from intracellular to extracellular compartments, aiding in plasma volume expansion.
  • Caution: Careful electrolyte and osmolality monitoring is required to avoid complications like osmotic demyelination. There is also a potential to cause fluid overload and hypernatremia, not recommended as a maintenance fluid. (Option C)

0.9% Normal Saline (Option A): It may lead to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis due to its high chloride content.

5% Dextrose in Water (Option D):

  • This hypotonic solution is used primarily for free water replacement, not surgical maintenance.
  • It is usually used perioperatively and must be avoided in the postoperative period as it can severely dilute plasma electrolytes and osmolality.

Note: An isotonic solution in the postoperative period could lead to potential GI dysfunction, when administered in excess, due to increased mucosal edema.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with recurrent episodes of chest pain radiating to her left arm and jaw that occur at rest and are not triggered by physical exertion. ECG during an episode shows transient ST-segment elevation. Troponin levels are normal. Which type of angina is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Prinzmetal Angina

 

Explanation:

Angina pectoris is characterized by paroxysmal and usually recurrent attacks of substernal or precordial chest discomfort caused by transient myocardial ischemia without the death of myocytes.

 

Type

Stable Angina (Option A)

Prinzmetal variant angina

Unstable or crescendo angina (Option B)

Trigger

 Physical exertion/stress At rest At rest or minimal exertion

Cause

 Chronic coronary stenosis

Coronary vasospasm

 Plaque disruption, ↑ MI risk

Treatment response

Responds well.

Responds well.

Need immediate medical intervention.

Silent angina (Option C) is asymptomatic myocardial ischemia, detected incidentally on ECG, stress test, or Holter.

questions.text: 30 year old  female presents with complaints of progressive weakness of lower limbs, numbness, difficulty walking and recent onset forgetfulness. On examination, bilateral loss of vibration sense is noted , bilateral ankle jerks are absent with bilateral babinski sign. Romberg sign is present with eyes closed. Peripheral blood smear done was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Subacute combined demyelination of Spinal cord

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Subacute combined demyelination of Spinal cord

 

Explanation:

This clinical scenario is classic for Subacute Combined Degeneration  due to Vitamin B12 deficiency, which affects both the dorsal columns (causing loss of vibration sense, positive Romberg sign) and the lateral corticospinal tracts (causing weakness and bilateral Babinski sign). The presence of absent ankle jerks with extensor plantar response suggests a mixed UMN and LMN picture seen in SACD as it involves both peripheral nerves and dorsal column. 

Note that neurological features can exist without hematological featuers. 

Incorrect options 

Tabes dorsalis also affects dorsal columns and can cause sensory ataxia, but there is no UMN involvement (Babinski sign would not be present). 
Friedreich’s ataxia has onset in adolescence and has cardiomyopathy, and a family history, which are not mentioned.
Brown-Séquard syndrome presents with  ipsilateral motor and vibration loss with contralateral pain loss not a bilateral symmetrical presentation as seen here.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents to the clinic with worsening dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, and ankle swelling. He has a past medical history of chronic heart failure, which was diagnosed 5 years ago. Despite being on several medications, he continues to experience symptoms. On examination, his heart rate is irregular and there is evidence of jugular venous distension. What is the drug of choice for managing his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D): Digoxin

Explanation:

Digoxin, a cardiac glycoside, is commonly used to manage chronic heart failure with atrial fibrillation and rapid ventricular response. It helps control heart rate and improve symptoms in patients with atrial fibrillation.

  • Digoxin at therapeutic concentrations mildly inhibits the cardiac Na+/K+ ATPase, causing an increase in intracellular Na+.
  • Increased Na+ inhibits Ca2+ extrusion via the NCX, resulting in higher intracellular Ca2+ and enhanced contractility.
  • The increased contractility and cardiac output provide symptomatic relief (primarily in systolic dysfunction) in patients with heart failure.
  • When the main trigger for neurohumoral activation is removed, sympathetic nerve tone, heart rate, and peripheral vascular resistance drop.
  • The decrease in preload and afterload reduces chamber dilation and wall stress.
  • Increased renal perfusion lowers renin production and increases diuresis, further decreasing preload.

Lisinopril (Option A) is an ACE inhibitor used in heart failure, but does not directly address the patient's atrial fibrillation or rapid ventricular response.

Carvedilol (Option B) is a beta-blocker used in heart failure but does not specifically target atrial fibrillation.

Furosemide (Option C) is a loop diuretic that manages fluid overload in heart failure but does not address the patient's arrhythmia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has a history of progressive nasal obstruction, recurrent nosebleeds, and crusting. On examination, she has a nasal deformity with a firm mass in the nasal cavity. A biopsy of the mass shows Mikulicz cells and is positive for Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. What is the most appropriate treatment strategy for this patient?

choices.text: Prolonged course of tetracycline and streptomycin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Prolonged course of tetracycline and streptomycin

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation with histopathology showing Mikulicz cells and a positive test for Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis is consistent with rhinoscleroma.
  • The primary treatment is combined streptomycin and tetracycline for a minimum duration of 4-6 weeks.

 

Treatment of Rhinoscleroma:

Medical therapy:

  • Streptomycin + tetracycline for a minimum duration of 4-6 weeks. (Option A)
  • After 1 month it is repeated if necessary.
  • Treatment is stopped only if two consecutive cultures from the biopsy material are negative.
  • To reduce fibrosis steroids can be combined (Option C)

 

Surgery: (Option D)

  • Surgical debridement, laser ablation, and correction of sclerotic defects.
  • These are considered only secondary to antibiotic therapy.

 

Amphotericin B (Option B): This antifungal is used to treat fungal infections like aspergillosis and mucormycosis. It is not used to treat rhinoscleroma, a bacterial infection.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with type 2 diabetes mellitus managed on metformin presents to the clinic with increased blood glucose levels. Routine investigations revealed haemoglobin of 11 g/dL, serum creatinine of 2.3, and an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 30 mL/min/1.73 m2. Which of the following additional medications can be safely prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Linagliptin

 

Explanation:

  • This patient should be started on linagliptin, a DPP-4 inhibitor that requires no dosage adjustment for renal impairment in this patient with type-2 diabetes and end-stage kidney disease (eGFR = 30 mL/min/1.73 m2).

 

 

Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors:

MOA
  • Increase Incretin Levels: Prevents degradation of incretin hormones (GLP-1 and GIP)
  • Enhance Insulin Secretion from the pancreas in response to meals. (no risk of hypoglycemia)
  • Reduce Glucagon Secretion
  • Maintain neutral weight

Uses
  • Oral hypoglycemic drug (type-2 diabetes)

Drugs
  1. Linagliptin: Safe in renal failure
  2. Teneligliptin: Safe in renal failure
  3. Vildagliptin: Hepatotoxic
  4. Alogliptin
  5. Sitagliptin
  6. Saxagliptin: (Option B)
    1. Metabolised by CYP3A4, it has more drug interactions.
    2. Requires dose adjustment in renal impairment.
    3. Risk of congestive heart failure.

Side effects
  • Nausea and vomiting (most common)
  • Pancreatitis (lesser than GLP-1)
  • Risk of pancreatic and thyroid cancer (lesser than GLP-1)
  • Arthritis, Nasopharyngitis:
    • Increase interleukins and cytokines levels (similar structure to CD26)
  • Hypersensitivity reactions: Steven-Johnson syndrome, angioedema


 

Dapagliflozin (Option A), an SGLT-2 inhibitor, is not recommended for use to improve glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus whose eGFR is less than 45 mL/min/1.73 m2.

 

Exenatide (Option C), a GLP-1 analogue, is avoided in patients with end-stage renal disease or ischemic renal failure due to hypovolemia.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with frequent falls, difficulty climbing stairs, and an unusual way of getting up from the floor. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in a gene associated with a severe muscle disorder. Which of the following statements about the involved gene is true?

choices.text: Associated with a condition that primarily affects females
The Gene’s product is a component of the sarcomere.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Largest in the human genome

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation with frequent falls, difficulty climbing stairs and unusual way of getting up (Gower sign) points towards Duchenne muscular Dystrophy.
  • Inherited in X-linked Recessive pattern - Primarily affects males (Option C).
  • The gene affected is Dystrophin, which is the largest gene in the human genome, located on the X chromosome (Option A).
  • Dystrophin is a crucial protein found in muscle cells that helps maintain the muscle fibre's structural integrity. It acts as a bridge between sarcolemma and the internal cytoskeleton, which helps in stabilization.

 

Option D: Dystrophin is not a component of the sarcomere but is crucial for anchoring the cytoskeleton to the muscle cell membrane. Sarcomere components involved in contraction include actin and myosin.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of muscle weakness, fatigue, and frequent urination. Her blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg. Investigations: Serum K+: 2.8 mEq/L, Serum Na+: 148 mEq/L, Plasma aldosterone: 35 ng/dL, Plasma renin activity: 0.2 ng/mL/h. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Conn’s syndrome

Explanation: The likely diagnosis from the given scenario is Conn's syndrome, also known as primary hyperaldosteronism, which is due to autonomous overproduction of aldosterone, usually from an adrenal adenoma.

  • It is characterised by resistant hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis.
  • Causes:
    • Aldosterone-producing adenoma (Conn's adenoma) - Most common.
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia.
  • Symptoms often include muscle weakness, fatigue, headaches, and frequent urination.
  • Laboratory findings:
    • Elevated plasma aldosterone levels
    • Suppressed plasma renin activity
    • High aldosterone-to-renin ratio
  • Treatment involves surgical removal of the adenoma and the use of mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists, such as spironolactone and eplerenone.

Role of Aldosterone: It acts on the collecting duct to –

  • Increase sodium reabsorption via epithelial sodium channels (ENaC).
  • Enhance potassium secretion through potassium channels (ROMK).

Bartter's syndrome(Option A)

  • It is a genetic disorder,childhood-onset, affecting the kidneys, leading to abnormalities in electrolyte reabsorption.
  • Typically presents with low blood pressure, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, elevated renin levels, and high urinary calcium excretion (hypercalciuria).

Gitelman's syndrome:(Option B)

  • A genetic disorder affects the distal convoluted tubule of the kidney, leading to hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and metabolic alkalosis.
  • Typically presents with low or normal blood pressure and low urinary calcium excretion (hypocalciuria).

Liddle's syndrome(Option D)

  • It is a genetic disorder caused by the increased activity of epithelial sodium channels (ENaC), leading to sodium retention and potassium excretion.
  • It has low aldosterone and renin levels and typically presents with hypertension.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with persistent knee pain and swelling of two months duration. The pain is severe at night and not relieved by NSAIDs. A biopsy was performed, and it showed pleomorphism, large hyperchromatic nuclei, and bizarre giant cells producing unmineralised osteoid. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: C) Osteosarcoma

EXPLANATION: The clinical presentation is suggestive of osteosarcoma, characterised by presence of pleomorphism, large hyperchromatic nuclei, and bizarre giant cells producing unmineralised osteoid

Osteosarcoma:

  • It is the most common primary malignant tumour of bone.
  • Tumours usually arise in the metaphyseal region of the long bones (distal femur or proximal tibia).
  • Genetic associations:
    • RB gene (most common)
    • TP53.
    • CDKN2A (also known as INK4a).
    • MDM2 and CDK4.
  • Morphology:
    • Osteosarcomas are bulky, gritty, grey-white tumours that often contain haemorrhage and cystic degeneration.
    • Histology demonstrate pleomorphism, large hyperchromatic nuclei, bizarre tumour giant cells, and abundant mitoses.
    • Extensive necrosis and intravascular invasion are also common.
    • Diagnosis of osteosarcoma requires the presence of malignant tumour cells producing unmineralised osteoid or mineralised bone.

Osteoid Osteoma (Option A): Small benign tumor. Severe night pain, but typically relieved by NSAIDs. Histology: woven bone and osteoblasts, but no marked pleomorphism or malignant features. No unmineralised osteoid with atypia

Osteoblastoma (Option B): Benign, larger than osteoid osteoma. May cause chronic pain, less responsive to NSAIDs than osteoid osteoma. Histology: Similar to osteoid osteoma but larger, more vascular, no marked pleomorphism or malignant osteoid production

Osteoclastoma  (Option D):(Giant Cell Tumor): Typically occurs in young adults. Involves epiphysis of long bones, not metaphysis. Histology: multinucleated giant cells, but no malignant osteoid, and no pleomorphic malignant osteoblasts

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after a motor vehicle accident. He displays significant behavioral changes including placing non-food objects in his mouth, increased sexual advances towards staff, and appears to have no fear when approached by the medical team. Which of the following brain structures is MOST likely to be damaged in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Amygdala

 

Explanation:

The case presents a patient with classic symptoms of Klüver-Bucy syndrome, including a lack of fear, oral tendencies, and hypersexuality.

  • It is a rare behavioral disorder that can occur after damage to the anterior temporal lobes, including the amygdalae, which are almond-shaped groups of nuclei located deep within the temporal lobes.
  • The amygdala is responsible for processing emotions, especially fear and reward.

The symptoms of Klüver-Bucy syndrome are varied but can include the following:

  • Lack of Fear: Individuals may show no fear of objects or situations that would normally elicit a fear response.
  • Excessive Curiosity: They may display an intense interest in exploring their surroundings, often in a non-directed and inappropriate manner.
  • Memory Impairment: Short-term memory is often significantly affected, leading to an inability to recall recent events.
  • Oral Tendencies: A tendency to put objects in their mouth, even those that are not edible.
  • Hypersexuality: An increased and often inappropriate sexual drive.

 

Cerebellum (Option A): Responsible for motor coordination and balance. Damage → ataxia, dysmetria, intention tremor. Does not cause behavioral symptoms like hypersexuality or hyperorality.

Hippocampus (Option C): Critical for forming new memories. Damage → anterograde amnesia. Does not cause hypersexuality or placidity.

Parietal lobe (Option D): Involved in spatial awareness, sensory integration, and body awareness. Damage can cause hemineglect, apraxia, or Gerstmann syndrome. Behavioral disinhibition is not typical.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male with small cell carcinoma of the lung presents with cyanosis of the neck and face, epistaxis, headache, dizziness and swelling over the face, neck and upper chest. He is irregular regarding chemotherapy sessions. Chest x-ray revealed a widening of the superior mediastinum. What is the investigation of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) CT scan

 

Explanation:

  • The given scenario suggests superior vena cava syndrome (SVC), and a CT scan is the investigation choice for this condition.

 

Superior Vena Cava (SVC) syndrome:

  • It occurs when the superior vena cava is obstructed, often due to bulky mediastinal lymph nodes or a right upper lobe tumour compressing or invading the vessel.
  • This obstruction severely reduces venous return from the head, neck, and upper extremities, leading to clinical manifestations such as:
    • Variable degrees of swelling of head, neck and arms along with cyanosis.
    • Headache, conjunctival oedema, dizziness, and syncope can be seen
    • Some other features, such as nasal stuffiness, epistaxis, and tongue swelling, may also be seen.
    • Dyspnea, dysphagia, cough and hoarseness of voice can also be seen in case of compression of mediastinal structures.

  • Chest X-ray suggests a widening of superior mediastinum (Option A).
  • The investigation of choice is CT scan (Option D).
  • MRI (Option B) and ultrasound (Option C) are not the investigations of choice, though mediastinal mass can be seen and diagnosed.
  • Management of this syndrome depends on the cause.
  • In cases of tracheal obstruction, a tracheostomy might be done.

questions.text: A newborn is examined shortly after delivery. The physician observes a localized swelling on the baby’s head that appears several hours after birth. The swelling is confined to one side of the skull, is firm to the touch, and does not cross the suture lines. What is the most likely diagnosis for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cephalohematoma

Explanation:

Cephalohematoma refers to a localized collection of blood between the skull and the periosteum, often appearing several hours after birth. It is typically unilateral, firm to the touch, and confined by the suture lines, matching the characteristics noted in the scenario.

Feature

 Cephalohematoma

Caput Succedaneum (Option A)

Definition

Blood collection between the periosteum and skull due to a ruptured emissary vein, often from trauma (e.g., forceps delivery).

Swelling from fluid accumulation between scalp layers, typically from prolonged pressure (e.g., during labor).

Situation

Generally unilateral, commonly over the parietal bone.

Can be bilateral, covering a broader area of the scalp.

Impulse on Crying

(Seen in hydrocephalus)

No impulse seen.

No impulse seen.

Limitation by Suture Line

Confined by sutures.

No restriction by sutures.

Underlying Pathology

May involve a skull fracture.

Non-pathological; usually harmless.

Occurrence

Does not appear at birth, and usually develops later.

Present at birth.

Development and Disappearance

Appears 12–24 hours after birth, and resolves in 6–8 weeks. Maybe followed by jaundice.

Disappears on its own within 24 hours. Maybe followed by jaundice.

Medico-Legal Importance

Can assist in determining how long the infant survived post-birth based on regression.

Provides clear evidence of in-utero life, though, in prolonged labor, fetal death may occur before birth.

Hydrocephalus (Option C) involves fluid accumulation in the brain ventricles, leading to overall head enlargement rather than localized swelling.

Intracranial hemorrhage (Option D) involves bleeding within the skull, typically presenting with more severe symptoms and not as a confined scalp swelling.

questions.text: A 32 y/o woman with a history of 3 first-trimester miscarriages and regular menstrual cycles had an HSG showing an indented external uterine contour. MRI confirms two separate endometrial cavities with a partial outer uterine indentation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bicornuate uterus

Explanation:

Differentiating a Bicornuate and Septate Uterus plays a crucial role in arriving at a diagnosis.

  • 3D sonography and MRI provide accurate assessments.

Gold standard- Hysteroscopy + Diagnostic Laparoscopy

SEPTATE UTERUS

(Option A)

Aspect

BICORNUATE UTERUS

(Option B)

<75°, Acute

Intercornual angle

>105°, Obtuse

<4 cm

Distance b/w horns

>4 cm

>5 mm

Distance b/w Endometrium to fundus

<5 mm

Hysteroscopic Septal Resection

Treatment

Strassman or Jone's Metroplasty

Flat/ convex (normal)

Fundal contour (external)

Concave/indented

 

Diagrammatic Representation

 

 


Didelphys uterus (Option C) arises from the complete failure of the fusion of the Mullerian ducts, resulting in two separate uterine cavities, each with its cervix. It can also present with two vaginas. On HSG/MRI, two separate uterine bodies with no connection between them are seen.

There is an increased incidence of breech and preterm labor.

Representation

HSG of Didelphys uterus

 

Unicornuate uterus (Option D) is caused by the failure to develop one of the Mullerian ducts. This results in a single uterine cavity and fallopian tubeIt appears smaller and curved to one side(banana-shaped), unlike a bicornuate uterus (heart-shaped).

 

 

Representation

HSG of Unicornuate uterus

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient is admitted to the hospital with high fever, chills, and severe headache. Upon examination and laboratory tests, he is diagnosed with P.falciparum malaria. The patient's medical history reveals that he has schizophrenia and is currently on antipsychotic medication. Considering the patient's medical history, which of the following antimalarial treatments is contraindicated for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mefloquine

Explanation:

  • Mefloquine is contraindicated in patients with a history of psychiatric disorders such as schizophrenia.
  • Mefloquine can exacerbate psychiatric symptoms, potentially leading to severe psychiatric reactions, including anxiety, paranoia, depression, hallucinations, and even suicidal thoughts.

questions.text: During the third week of gestation, the formation of the primitive streak signifies the start of gastrulation. Which statement about the primitive streak accurately describes this process?

choices.text: It forms from hypoblast cells and establishes the embryonic central axis.
It appears dorsally, becoming linear and marking the transition to a trilaminar disc.
It develops into the prechordal plate, defining the head-tail axis.
It originates from trophoblast cells, contributing to the amniotic cavity and yolk sac formation.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It appears dorsally, becoming linear and marking the transition to a trilaminar disc.

 

Explanation:

  • The primitive streak is a key structure that forms on the dorsal aspect of the embryonic disc and becomes a linear structure as the disc elongates.
  • This marks the beginning of gastrulation and the transition from a bilaminar to a trilaminar disc, establishing the embryonic axis.

 

  • The primitive streak is an early, temporary structure that emerges in the blastula during the initial stages of embryonic development.
  • Around the 15th day of development, following the formation of the prechordal plate, epiblast cells along the central axis near the tail end of the embryo start to proliferate, creating an elevation that protrudes into the amniotic cavity known as the primitive streak. (Option A, B and D)
  • Its cranial end forms the primitive node.
  • A groove called a primitive groove appears in the primitive streak, which continues with a small depression, a primitive pit, in the primitive node.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with ongoing tearing and discharge from the right eye. Despite regular lacrimal sac massage and topical antibiotics, the symptoms persist. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Continue lacrimal sac massage and antibiotics

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Probing of the nasolacrimal duct

​​​​​​​Explanation:

  • In congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction (CNLDO), persistent symptoms beyond 6–8 months of age, despite conservative management (e.g., Crigler massage and antibiotics), warrant nasolacrimal duct probing.
     
  • Since this child is 9 months old with no response to massage and antibiotics, the next step is probing, which is often successful when done before 12 months.
     

Congenital Nasolacrimal Duct Obstruction (CNLDO):

Aspect

Details

Definition

Blockage of the nasolacrimal duct, usually at the valve of Hasner

Typical Age

Present from birth or early infancy

Symptoms

• Chronic tearing (epiphora)

• Discharge

• Recurrent conjunctivitis

First-Line Management

• Crigler massage to open the duct

• Topical antibiotics for infection

Indications for Probing

• Persistence beyond 6–10 months

• Repeated infections or failure of conservative therapy

Prognosis with Probing

>90% success if performed before 12–15 months

 

Continue massage and antibiotics (Option A): Incorrect because symptoms have already persisted beyond the expected resolution time despite these measures.
 

Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) (Option C): Incorrect as DCR is reserved for older children or adults when probing and intubation fail.
 

Balloon catheter dilation (Option D): Incorrect because balloon dacryoplasty is typically considered for recurrent or failed probing, not first-line.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a breast lump. On biopsy, the tissue shows anaplastic cells without any differentiation. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) staining is performed to characterise the tumour further. Which marker would be most appropriate to confirm the epithelial origin of the tumour cells in breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) CK7

Explanation:

In a female with a breast lump and presence of anaplastic cells, CK7 (cytokeratin 7) is the most appropriate marker to confirm the epithelial origin of the tumor, as cytokeratins are commonly expressed in all carcinomas.

  • In Immunohistochemistry (IHC), a CK7 and CK20 profile is commonly used to help determine the tumor origin.

  • Most female-origin cancers (breast, endometrial, thyroid, cervical) typically show a CK7-positive and CK20-negative pattern. (Option D)

  • ER (estrogen receptor), PR (progesterone receptor), and HER2 (human epidermal growth factor receptor 2) are other markers that can be positive in breast cancer, which help in deciding management.

 

CD20 (Option A) is a B-cell marker that is typically positive in B-cell lymphomas, including non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL).

Pp3 (Option B) is a marker positive in squamous cell carcinoma in the lung.

TTF-1(thyroid transcription factor-1) (Option D) is a marker positive in the adenocarcinoma of the lung.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient is undergoing major abdominal surgery under general anesthesia. After induction of anesthesia, the patient's CVP is measured at 3 cm H2O. The patient’s heart rate is 110/min, blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management step based on the CVP and clinical findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Administer a fluid bolus

Explanation:

Low CVP (3 cm H2O) suggests hypovolemia, which is consistent with the patient's tachycardia and hypotension. Administering a fluid bolus is the first-line treatment to increase preload and improve hemodynamics.

 

Central Venous Pressure (CVP) Monitoring:

CVP measures the pressure in the thoracic vena cava near the right atrium, reflecting right ventricular preload and overall fluid status.

Measurement Method (Invasive):

Central venous catheter placed in large veins (e.g., subclavian or internal jugular), connected to a pressure transducer

Normal Range: 3-8 mmHg.

Low CVP Causes:

  • Hypovolemia (blood loss or dehydration).
  • Venodilation (e.g., in septic shock).

Elevated CVP Causes:

  • Heart failure, fluid overload, valve dysfunction.
  • Increased intrathoracic pressure (e.g., mechanical ventilation, tension pneumothorax).

Clinical Use:

  • Guides fluid resuscitation.
  • Helps assess heart function and venous return.

 

Vasopressors (Option A) may be required if hypotension persists after adequate fluid resuscitation, but not as the initial step.

Blood transfusion (Option C) is not indicated unless there is evidence of blood loss or anemia.

Increasing anesthetic depth (Option D) is inappropriate here, as the patient is likely hypovolemic.

questions.text: A patient with a history of cardiovascular disease is advised by their doctor to incorporate oils rich in polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) into their diet, with a recommendation of oils containing more than 50% PUFA. Which of the following oils would not be recommended?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Coconut Oil

Explanation:

Coconut oil is primarily composed of saturated fats, with very low levels of polyunsaturated fats. It contains approximately 6% PUFA, significantly lower than oils like safflower, sunflower, and soybean oils, which contain more than 50% PUFA.

Due to its high saturated fat content, coconut oil raises LDL cholesterol levels and potentially increases the risk of cardiovascular disease.

 

 

PUFA

Safflower Oil (Option A)

75

Sunflower Oil (Option B)

62

Soybean Oil(Option C)

53

Groundnut Oil

32

Palm Oil

11

Coconut Oil (Option D)

2

Butter

2


Polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA):

  • They are dietary fats characterised by having more than one double bond.
  • Types: omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids.
  • Role in cardiovascular health:
    • Lowers levels of triglycerides (a type of fat in the blood).
    • Reduce LDL cholesterol, thereby improving the lipid profile and reducing the risk of atherosclerosis and cardiovascular disease.

 

Oils rich in PUFA, such as safflower (Option A), sunflower(Option B), and soybean oils(Option C), are recommended for heart health because they improve blood cholesterol levels and reduce the risk of cardiovascular events when consumed in moderation.

questions.text: Carlos, a 40-year-old father and avid hiker, arrives at the emergency department after being bitten by a stray dog on his forearm while out on a rural trail. The bite is deep enough that it has broken the skin, causing some bleeding. Carlos mentions he's never received a rabies vaccination before and is anxious about the possibility of infection. What is the most appropriate next step in managing Carlos’s injury?

choices.text: Clean the wound and reassure Carlos that no further treatment is necessary.
Clean the wound and administer a series of rabies vaccines on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14, without giving Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG).
Thoroughly wash the wound, administer rabies vaccines on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14, and provide Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) around the wound site.
Give Carlos a single dose of rabies vaccine and Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) for rapid immunity.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thoroughly wash the wound, administer rabies vaccines on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14, and provide Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) around the wound site.

Explanation:

  • Carlos’s injury is classified as a Category III exposure because the bite broke the skin and caused bleeding.
  • For Category III exposures, particularly in unvaccinated individuals, treatment requires thorough wound cleaning, a full series of rabies vaccinations, and Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) around the wound to provide immediate passive immunity.

Categories of dog bite and management:

Category

Exposure Type

Management

Category I

  • Touching or feeding animals

  • Licking of intact skin

  • Ensure proper hygiene

  • No treatment required

Category II

  • Nibbling on uncovered skin

  • Minor scratches or abrasions without bleeding

  • Immediate wound washing with soap and water

  • Rabies vaccination:

    • Unvaccinated: Days 0, 3, 7, and 14

    • Previously vaccinated: Booster doses on Days 0 and 3

    • No Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) required

Category III

  • Bites or scratches with bleeding

  • Licks on broken skin

  • Exposure to mucous membranes (mouth, eyes, nose)

  • Immediate wound washing with soap and water, flush for at least 15 minutes.

  • Suture: Do not suture the wound immediately, as it may spread the virus, instead delay it for 24 to 48 hours.

  • Rabies vaccination:

    • Unvaccinated: Full PEP series on Days 0, 3, 7, and 14

    • Previously vaccinated: Booster doses on Days 0 and 3

 

  • Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG):

    • Equine immunoglobulin or ERIG
    • Human rabies Immunoglobulin or HRIG
      • Preferred (free from the danger of sensitisation, HIV and hepatitis viruses)
      • Dose: – 40 IU / kg IM
      • Started on Day 0 along with vaccination (can be given up to 7 days).
      • 70% is given around the wound and, the rest is given distant from the wound.

  • Required for unvaccinated individuals

  • Not needed for previously vaccinated individuals

 Simply cleaning the wound is not enough for rabies prevention after a deep bite from a potentially rabid animal. (Option A)

 RIG is required for unvaccinated individuals with significant exposure to provide immediate antibodies at the wound site (Option B)

 A single dose of rabies vaccine is not sufficient to confer lasting immunity, and the full vaccination series is needed along with RIG for adequate post-exposure prophylaxis (Option D)

questions.text:
Match the type of cyst with the correct description of it.


	
		
			
			Types of Cysts
			
			
			Description
			
		
		
			
			1. Functional cyst
			
			
			A. A mucus-filled cyst on the cervix
			
		
		
			
			2. Gartner’s cyst
			
			
			B. Forms due to remnants of the Wolffian duct
			
		
		
			
			3. Skene’s cyst
			
			
			C. Located near the urethra in females
			
		
		
			
			4. Nabothian cyst
			
			
			D. Commonly occurs in the ovaries
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-D, 2-B, 3-C, 4-A

 

Explanation:

Type of Cyst

Description

Details

Functional Cyst

Fluid-filled sacs that form on the ovaries, typically during the menstrual cycle.
  •  2 Types:
    1. Follicular cysts form due to hormonal dysfunction prior to ovulation, leading to expansion of the follicular antrum with serous fluid.
    2. Corpus luteum cysts form due to excessive hemorrhage from the vascular corpus luteum following ovulation.
  • High-dose combination oral contraceptives (COCs) suppress ovarian activity and protect against cyst development.
  • Surgical excision is considered for large, persistent cysts or smaller ones causing persistent symptoms. Usually benign and not cancerous.

Gartner’s Cyst

Forms from remnants of the Wolffian duct
  • Located along vaginal walls
  • Can cause discomfort, urinary issues, or dyspareunia if large
  • Treatment may involve surgical removal if symptomatic

Skene’s Cyst

Located near the urethra in females, formed from the Skene’s glands.
  • Involved in lubrication of the urethral opening. Usually presents as a urethral diverticulum.
  • Cysts here can cause urinary problems, pain, or discomfort.
  • Treatment may include antibiotics for infection or surgical drainage/removal if necessary.

Nabothian Cyst

Mucus-filled cysts that occur on the cervix.
  • Form when mucus-producing glands in the cervix are covered by skin cells, trapping the mucus.
  • Generally harmless, asymptomatic and often found during routine pelvic exams.
  • No treatment is typically required unless they cause significant symptoms, in which case they can be drained or removed.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, who gave birth 3 months ago, presents with symptoms of anxiety, palpitations, and weight loss. Her thyroid function tests reveal abnormalities. What is the most likely phase of postpartum thyroiditis she is experiencing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Thyrotoxic phase

Explanation:

Postpartum thyroiditis:

Definition

Postpartum thyroiditis is an inflammation of the thyroid gland that occurs after childbirth, typically within the first year postpartum

Etiology
  • Autoimmune Factors
  • Genetic Predisposition
  • Hormonal Changes

Clinical manifestations

It has 2 phases which has a clinical progression-

Thyrotoxic phase( 1-4 months) (Option A)

Hypothyroid phase( 4 to 8 months) (Option B)

The hypothyroid phase either leads to euthyroid phase (Option C) or permanent hypothyroidism (Option D).

Investigation

Thyroid Function Tests:

  • TSH: Elevated in the hypothyroid phase, suppressed in the hyperthyroid phase.
  • Free T4: Elevated in the hyperthyroid phase, decreased in the hypothyroid phase.
  • Free T3: May also be elevated in the hyperthyroid phase.

Thyroid Antibodies:

  • Anti-thyroid Peroxidase (Anti-TPO) Antibodies: Often elevated, indicating an autoimmune component.

Treatment:
  1. Hyperthyroid phase- Beta blockers
  2. Hypothyroid phase- Levothyroxine, (25 mcg to 75 mcg)

questions.text: A 32 y/o woman at 12 weeks gestation with a history of mitral valve prolapse denies chest pain, shortness of breath, and syncope. What is her prognosis for this pregnancy?

choices.text: Good prognosis with minimal risk of complications.
Poor prognosis with a high risk of heart failure.
Moderate prognosis with potential for arrhythmias.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Good prognosis with minimal risk of complications.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Pregnancy may improve the alignment of the mitral valve due to increased blood volume, leading to fewer complications. Because the patient is asymptomatic (denying chest pain, shortness of breath, and syncope), she is likely to have a good prognosis.

 

Prognosis

Heart Condition

Good prognosis with minimal complications
(Option A)
  • Mitral valve prolapse without pathological myxomatous degeneration.
  • Small to moderate-sized ventricular septal defects (VSDs).
  • Repaired transposition of the great vessels.
  • Atrial septal defect (ASD) unless pulmonary hypertension has developed.
  • Mild MS and AS.

Poor prognosis with high risk of heart failure.

(Option B)
  • Eisenmenger syndrome.
  • Severe aortic stenosis.
  • Severe coarctation of the aorta.
  • Uncorrected Cyanotic Heart Disease.
  • Idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension.
  • Prior myocardial infarction, especially with diabetes-associated ischemic heart disease.
  • Marfan Syndrome with Aortic Root Dilation

Moderate prognosis with potential for arrhythmias.

(Option C)
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
  • Dilated Cardiomyopathy
  • Mitral stenosis.
  • Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia.

Uncertain prognosis requiring frequent monitoring (Option D)
  • Peripartum cardiomyopathy.
  • Mechanical heart valve.

questions.text:
Match the following genes involved in the development of depression with their normal functions.

 


	
		
			
			Genes 
			
			
			Encoded for 
			
		
		
			
			A) SLC6A4
			
			
			i) Serotonin receptor
			
		
		
			
			B) DRD4
			
			
			ii) Dopamine transporter
			
		
		
			
			C) HTR1A
			
			
			iii) Serotonin transporter
			
		
		
			
			D) SLC6A3
			
			
			iv) Dopamine receptor
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii

 

Explanation:

 

Genetic Influence
  • About one-third of major depression risk is attributed to genetic factors.
  • The gene encoding of serotonin receptor: HTR1A
  • The gene for serotonin transporter: 5HTTP/SLC6A4
  • The gene for dopamine receptor: DRD4
  • The gene for dopamine transporter: SLC6A3

Family History
  • Risk increases 2.5–3 times if a first-degree relative has depression.
  • Life events can raise risk from 5 to 16 times shortly after occurrence.

Neurobiological Mechanisms

Studies show that individuals with the short allele of 5-HTTLPR (serotonin transporter gene) exhibit amygdala hyperreactivity to emotional threats

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with an erythematous plaque over the dorsum of hand that has been there for 4 years and is slowly progressing. Examination revealed a well-demarcated, indurated, annular-shaped plaque with irregular borders that was progressing towards one side and scarring on another border. Which of the following statements is FALSE about this condition?

choices.text: It occurs in a previously sensitized patient
Apple jelly nodules can be seen

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) It is a multibacillary lesion

Explanation:

Based on the history and the image provided, the diagnosis is Lupus vulgaris and it is a chronic, progressive, paucibacillary (not multibacillary) form of cutaneous tuberculosis.

  • Lupus vulgaris is the most common form of cutaneous TB seen in adults (Most common in females).
  • Causative organisms: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Mycobacterium bovis.

Pathogenesis :

  • Route of spread: Endogenous spread or from exogenous inoculation.
  • It occurs in a previously sensitized individual with an increased cell-mediated immunity to tuberculin. (Option B)

Clinical features:

  • Presents as a single or a group of erythematous violaceous annular plaques with central scarring and atrophy with active margins. (Option C)
  • The periphery shows erythematous deep-seated nodules which on diascopy may stand out as apple jelly nodules. (Option D)
  • Most commonly seen in the buttocks, upper extremities, and face.
  • Papules may recur within scarred areas, enlarging and coalescing into large, firm, elevated plaques.

Complications:

  • Secondary scarring and squamous cell carcinoma may develop rarely.

Treatment :

  • Anti-tubercular drugs.

questions.text: Which of the following does this Darrow-Yannet diagram (Solid line represent the controlled condition and broken red-line indicates new-steady state condition) represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Diarrhea

 

Explanation:

The Darrow-Yannet diagram shows isosmotic volume contraction; an example of that is diarrhoea.

Darrow-Yannet Diagram:

  • It helps to understand the plasma osmolarity and volume alterations in various diseases.
  • The volume is plotted in x-axis and plasma osmolarity in y-axis.
  • Broken lines indicate the flow of water between compartments driven by osmotic gradients, reflecting passive movement in response to changes in solute concentrations.
  • A normal Darrow-Yannet Diagram is shown below:

Disorder

Examples

Effects

Isosmotic volume contraction
  • Diarrhoea
  • Vomiting
  • Haemorrhage
  • Burns
  • Decrease in ECF and plasma volumes
  • Increased plasma protein concentration
  • Increased hematocrit
  • Decreased arterial blood pressure

Hyposmotic volume contraction
  • Adrenocortical insufficiency
  • Gastric secretions loss
  • Decreased plasma volume
  • Decreased ECF and plasma osmolality
  • Water shifts from ECF to ICF
  • Cellular swelling
  • Decreased arterial blood pressure

Hyperosmotic volume contraction
  • Diabetes insipidus
  • Excessive sweating
  • Alcoholism
  • Fever
  • Decrease in ECF and plasma volumes
  • Increased ECF and plasma osmolality
  • Water shifts from ICF to ECF
  • Increased hematocrit
  • Decreased arterial blood pressure.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of mild lower abdominal pain and vaginal spotting. She has a history of 6 weeks of amenorrhea. On examination, she is hemodynamically stable, and a transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) reveals an adnexal mass of 3cm consistent with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy. No fetal cardiac activity is found. Her initial beta hCG level is measured at 2,000 IU/L. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Methotrexate therapy

Explanation:
Methotrexate therapy is the most appropriate management for a hemodynamically stable patient with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy and a beta hCG level less than 3,000 IU/L, provided the adnexal mass is less than 4 cm and there is no fetal cardiac activity.

Management of Unruptured Ectopic Tubal Pregnancy:

Management

Criteria/Indication

Description

Expectant Management
  • Beta hCG < 1,500 IU/L
  • No significant symptoms
  • Strong likelihood of spontaneous resolution
  • Monitoring without intervention, relying on the natural resolution of the ectopic pregnancy

Medical Management
  • Beta hCG < 3,000 IU/L
  • Adnexal mass < 4 cm
  • No fetal cardiac activity
  • Hemodynamically stable
  • Methotrexate (single dose/ multi-dose regimen) (best)
  • KCl (directly in sac)
  • Mifepristone
  • Prostaglandins

Surgical Management
  • Beta hCG > 5,000 IU/L
  • Size of ectopic > 4 cm
  • Presence of cardiac activity
  • Linear Salpingostomy (best)
  • Resection Anastomosis

questions.text: A CKD patient is determined to have adynamic bone disease. Which of the following is the best explanation for this presentation?

choices.text: Excessive use of vitamin D preparations and phosphate binders
Less use of vitamin D preparations and phosphate binders

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Excessive use of vitamin D preparations and phosphate binders:

  • Adynamic Bone Disease in CKD Characterized by low bone turnover (↓ osteoblast & osteoclast activity) and is often iatrogenic.
  • It results from over-suppression of PTH due to use of calcitriol and calcium-containing phosphate binders like calcium acetate and calcium carbonate.

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic, a six-year-old male presents with a history of frequent respiratory and skin infections, eczema flare-ups, and thrombocytopenia. Given these symptoms, which genetic evaluation method would be the most effective for confirming the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: B cell tyrosine kinase activity detection

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) WASP gene mutation

Explanation:

WASP gene mutation analysis, specific to Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive disease characterised by the triad of:

  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Eczema
  • Recurrent infections

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is caused by mutations in the gene located at Xp11.23, which encodes the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP).

  • WASP belongs to a family of proteins that are believed to link membrane receptors, such as antigen receptors, to cytoskeletal elements.
  • Patients do not make antibodies to polysaccharide antigens, and the response to protein antigens is poor.
  • IgM levels in the serum are low, but levels of IgG are usually normal.
  • Paradoxically, the levels of IgA and IgE are often elevated. Patients are also prone to developing B-cell lymphomas.
  • WASP may be involved in cytoskeleton-dependent responses, including cell migration and signal transduction, but the essential functions of this protein in lymphocytes and platelets are unclear.
  • It may lead to early death. The only treatment is HSC transplantation.

ANA titer (Option B): These are typically associated with SLE ( systemic lupus erythematosus )

FISH (Option C):

 

  • FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization) is a molecular cytogenetic technique used to detect and localize specific DNA sequences within the chromosomes. It uses fluorescently labelled probes that bind to their complementary sequences on chromosomes, allowing for visualization of specific genes or regions of interest under a fluorescence microscope
  • Also used in microdeletion, amplification or translocation.
  • FISH is an investigation of choice for Di-George syndrome.

B cell tyrosine kinase activity detection (Option D): Detection of B cell tyrosine kinase activity is relevant for X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA), characterized by the absence of mature B cells and low levels of immunoglobulins.

questions.text:
Match the following


	
		
			
			1) Ostecytes
			
			
			a) Connects Haversian canals
			
		
		
			
			2) Volkmann’s canals
			
			
			b) Contains vasculature, nerves, and lymphatics
			
		
		
			
			3) Canaliculi
			
			
			c) Formed from osteoblasts trapped in lacunae
			
		
		
			
			4) Haversian canal
			
			
			d) Facilitates communication between osteocytes
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b

 

Explanation:

1) Osteocytes

c) Formed from osteoblasts trapped in lacunae

2) Volkmann’s canals

a) Connects Haversian canals

3) Canaliculi

d) Facilitate communication between osteocytes

4) Haversian canal

b) Contains vasculature, nerves, and lymphatics

 

 

 

 

Osteon (aka Haversian system) - Structure and Morphology:

  • Osteons are cylindrical functional units of bone.
  • They primarily form in compact bone through continuous remodeling, particularly in adults.
  • In long bones, osteons are aligned parallel to each other, and the bone's long axis, appearing round in cross-sections.
  • Each osteon has a central Haversian canal, which allows vasculature, nerves, and lymphatics to pass through.
  • Osteoblasts produce 5–20 rings of lamellar bone that radiate outward from the Haversian canal.
  • Volkmann’s canals connect Haversian canals and run obliquely to the osteons.

 

 

 

 

Osteocyte Formation:

  • Osteocytes are osteoblasts that become trapped in lacunae as they secrete osteoid.
  • These osteocytes are aligned with the lamellar rings of the osteon.
  • Canaliculi are small channels that connect lacunae and radiate perpendicularly, allowing osteocytes to extend cellular processes and communicate through gap junctions.

 

Function:

  • Osteons provide mechanical support and strength to bones through their thick lamellar rings.
  • They protect the bone’s vascular supply and continuously remodel in response to biomechanical stress.

questions.text: A 3-y/o child is brought to the emergency department with symptoms of severe fatigue, vomiting, and episodes of hypoglycemia. Blood tests reveal low glucose levels without elevated ketone bodies, as indicated by a negative Rothera and Benedict tests. Further examination indicates a fatty liver. The child's mother gives h/o acute fatty liver during her pregnancy with the child. Which of the following deficiencies is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct answer : Option B- Long-Chain 3-Hydroxyacyl-CoA Dehydrogenase Deficiency 

  • The scenario describes a child with severe fatigue, vomiting, nonketotic hypoglycemia, and fatty liver, alongside a maternal history of acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP).
  • These features are characteristic of Long-Chain 3-Hydroxyacyl-CoA Dehydrogenase Deficiency.
    • This condition affects fatty acid oxidation and can manifest in both the child and mother, particularly with AFLP during pregnancy.
  • Other deficiencies listed do not specifically present with this combination of symptoms and maternal history.

 

FATTY ACID OXIDATION DEFECTS

CONGENITAL DEFECTS

ACQUIRED DEFECTS

1. CPT-I Deficiency:

  • Site: Liver
  • Pathophysiology: Leading to decreased fatty acid oxidation and ketogenesis, which can result in hypoglycemia (Option A ruled out)
 

2. CPT-II Deficiency:

  • Site: Primarily affecting skeletal muscle and potentially the liver in severe cases
 

3. Defects in β-oxidation Enzymes: 2 types:

 
  • Long and Short-Chain 3-Hydroxyacyl-CoA Dehydrogenase Deficiency: Can cause nonketotic hypoglycemia, coma, and fatty liver. May also contribute to acute fatty liver during pregnancy
 
  • 3-Ketoacyl-CoA Thiolase and HMG-CoA Lyase Deficiency: These deficiencies not only disrupt fatty acid oxidation but also affect the breakdown of leucine, a ketogenic amino acid.

1. Carnitine Deficiency:

  • Common in preterm babies
  • Cause:
    • Inadequate biosynthesis or renal leakage.
    • Hemolysis
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Impaired fatty acid oxidation→hypoglycemia & Lipid accumulation→muscular weakness (Option D ruled out)
 

2. Jamaican Vomiting Sickness:

 
  • Cause: Consuming unripe ackee fruit containing the toxin hypoglycin,
  • Pathophysiology: This condition inhibits medium- and short-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase, leading to hypoglycemia (Option C ruled out)

CLINICAL FEATURES
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Nonketotic Hypoglycemia
  • Lipid Accumulation
  • Dicarboxylic Aciduria
    • Marked by the excretion of C6—C10 ω-dicarboxylic acids and non-ketotic hypoglycemia
    • It arises from a lack of mitochondrial medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase.
  • Muscular Weakness due to the buildup of lipids in muscles
  • Coma
  • Fatty Liver
  • Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy: Due to Long-chain 3-hydroxyacyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency indicating a potential role of hormonal changes influencing enzyme activity.
  • Neurological Symptoms: Defects impacting fatty acid oxidation, especially those also affecting the breakdown of leucine.

 

Differential Diagnosis:

  1. DKA (Benedict+, Rothera+): This would present with high blood glucose and elevated ketone bodies, which is not the case here.
  2. Starvation ketosis (Benedict-, Rothera+): This can also cause non-ketotic hypoglycemia, but without the fatty liver findings.
  3. Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD): This amino acid disorder can impact fatty acid oxidation and cause hypoglycemia, but would likely present with a different pattern of symptoms.
  4. Type 1 Glycogen Storage Disease: This can also lead to fasting hypoglycemia, but would not typically involve fatty liver changes

questions.text: A baby is born to an HIV-positive mother. The mother has been on antiretroviral therapy (ART) for the past 6 months. What is the appropriate management for this newborn?

choices.text: Daily nevirapine prophylaxis starting at birth for 6 weeks
Zidovudine and nevirapine for 6 weeks if the baby is not breastfed
Zidovudine and nevirapine for 12 weeks if the baby is breastfed
Daily nevirapine prophylaxis starting at birth for 12 weeks

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Daily nevirapine prophylaxis starting at birth for 6 weeks.

 

Explanation:

Since the mother is on ART, the standard prophylaxis for the neonate is daily nevirapine starting at birth for 6 weeks. The other options are relevant for different scenarios or specific high-risk situations.

Management of a Baby Born to an HIV-Positive Mother

  • If the Mother is on ART:
    • Daily nevirapine prophylaxis starting at birth
    • Duration: 6 weeks (Option D)
  • For High-Risk Neonates: (Options B and C)
    • High-Risk Factors:
      • Mother not on ART or received ART for <4 weeks
      • High viral load in the mother (> 1000 copies/ml)
      • Newly identified with HIV within 2 weeks of delivery
    • Prophylaxis Regimen:
      • Two drugs: zidovudine + nevirapine
      • Duration:
        • If the baby is not breastfed: 6 weeks
        • If the baby is breastfed: 12 weeks

questions.text:
Which of the following factors are responsible for testicular descent?


	Testosterone
	Gubernaculum
	Intra-abdominal Pressure
	CGRP (Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide)
	INSL3 (Insulin-like 3)
	Processus Vaginalis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1,2,3,4,5,6

Explanation:

 

Factors responsible for testicular descent:

 

Factor

Role in Testicular Descent

Testosterone

Stimulates gubernaculum shortening, guiding the testes into the scrotum.

Gubernaculum

A ligament that pulls the testes down during descent.

Intra-abdominal Pressure

Helps push the testes through the inguinal canal.

CGRP (Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide)

Supports gubernaculum development during the early transabdominal phase.

INSL3 (Insulin-like 3)

Promotes gubernaculum elongation, aiding descent.

Processus Vaginalis

Provides the pathway through which the testes descend.

 

 

 

 

Position of Testis in Intrauterine Life


 

Abdomen (2nd Month/7th Week)

↓

Pelvis (Iliac Fossa) (3rd Month/12th Week)

↓

Deep Inguinal Ring (End of 6th Month/24th Week)

↓

Passes Through Inguinal Canal (During 7th Month/25th-28th Week)

↓

Superficial Inguinal Ring (8th Month/29th-32nd Week)

↓

Enters Scrotum (Beginning of 9th Month/33rd Week)

↓

Base of Scrotum (Before Birth/End of 9th Month/36th Week)

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of unsteady gait and frequent falls. Upon further inquiry, it is revealed that he has experienced progressive difficulty with coordination and balance over the past few years. His parents report a similar history in his older sister, who is now 15 years old. Interestingly, the parents are both asymptomatic, but the boy's maternal uncle was diagnosed with a similar condition in his late 20s. What is the most likely inheritance pattern seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Autosomal recessive


 

Explanation:

 

The progressive difficulty with coordination and balance in both siblings, along with the maternal uncle's being affected, suggests Friedreich's ataxia (A repeat expansion of the trinucleotide GAA (guanine-adenine-adenine), typically in the gene's first intron, is the leading cause of this disease) a pattern consistent with autosomal recessive inheritance. In this scenario, both parents are likely carriers of a defective gene responsible for Friedreich's ataxia, and each sibling has inherited two copies of the defective gene, resulting in the development of this disorder.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Examples of autosomal recessive disorders:

Mnemonic

Disease

Pasta
  • Phenylketonuria
  • Alkaptonuria
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Thalassemia

Fried
  • Friedrich’s ataxia:

Chawal
  • Cystic fibrosis, Congenital adrenal hyperplasia
  • Hemophilia C, Homocystinuria, Hemochromatosis
  • Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency
  • Wilson’s disease
  • Albinism
  • Lysosomal storage disorders, glycogen storage disorders

DNA repair defects

Big
  • Bloom syndrome

Fax
  • Fanconi’s anemia
  • Ataxia telangiectasia
  • Xeroderma pigmentosum

X-linked recessive (Option C) is less likely because the sister is affected (females are usually carriers).

X-linked dominant (Option B) and autosomal dominant (Option A)  are unlikely since parents are asymptomatic, and dominant conditions usually show up in at least one parent.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male presents with complaints of chronic indigestion, bloating and delayed gastric emptying. After a thorough evaluation, the physician prescribes a prokinetic agent to improve gastrointestinal motility.

Which of the following statements about prokinetic agents is false?

choices.text: Metoclopramide acts as a D2 antagonist and has serotonergic activity, enhancing GI motility.
Domperidone primarily acts as a peripheral D2 receptor antagonist, facilitating gastric emptying and increasing LES tone.
Erythromycin acts as a motilin receptor agonist, mimicking the action of motilin to stimulate gastric contractions.
Cholecystokinin acts on the CCK-A receptor and stimulates stomach contraction, promoting motility.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cholecystokinin acts on the CCK-A receptor and stimulates stomach contraction, promoting motility.

Explanation:

Cholecystokinin acts on the CCK A receptor to inhibit stomach contraction and not stimulate it.

Prokinetic agents:

Class of Drug

Drugs

Uses

Dopamine (D2) Receptor Antagonists

Metoclopramide, Domperidone, Levosulpiride

GERD, gastroparesis, dyspepsia, antiemetic. (Option A and B ruled out)

5-HT4 agonists

Cisapride, Tegaserod (banned due to QT prolongation),

Mosapride,Prucalopride, Cinitapride, Metoclopramide.

GERD, gastroparesis, dyspepsia.

Motilin receptor agonists

Erythromycin

In Acute Upper GI haemorrhage to promote gastric emptying of blood before endoscopy. (Option C ruled out)

CCK - A (CCK -1) inhibitors

Dexloxiglumide

GERD, IBS, functional dyspepsia, constipation and gastroparesis.

↑ ACh levels

Neostigmine

Postoperative paralytic ileus

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male with chronic leg swelling presents with difficulty pinching the skin over the dorsum of his foot. What is this sign known as?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stemmer's sign

Explanation:

The sign of inability to pinch a fold of skin at the root of the second toe suggesting lymphedema is known as Stemmer’s sign.

 

Clinical features of Lymphedema:

  • Buffalo hump: Refers to a fat pad that develops on the dorsum of foot, often associated with conditions like Cushing’s syndrome or prolonged use of corticosteroids. It is not related to skin pinching or lymphedema (Option A).
  • Square toes: The toes appear square-shaped due to prolonged confinement in tight footwear (Option B).
  • Stemmer's sign: Skin over the dorsum of the foot cannot be pinched because of subcutaneous fibrosis (Option C).

questions.text: A 7 y/o girl is brought to a makeshift medical camp that was set up following a massive earthquake 3 days ago. She has no prior history of vaccinations. The child was exposed to a confirmed case of measles two days ago. Which of the following would be your next step in helping the child?

choices.text: Administer typhoid and cholera vaccines first.
No vaccines are necessary at this time.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Administer the measles vaccine immediately.
 

Explanation:

In a disaster scenario, all vaccines are contraindicated for victims except the measles vaccine, which can be administered within 3 days of exposure to a confirmed case.

This is because measles has a natural incubation period of 10-14 days, and antibodies can be produced after vaccination within 7 to 10 days, which can help in preventing the disease and its outbreak.

Typhoid and cholera vaccines (Option B) are not given to all because the time needed to produce antibodies is longer than the natural incubation period of these diseases.

In a disaster situation, immediate protection is crucial, and these vaccines do not offer quick enough protection to be beneficial in the acute phase.

OPV (Option C) is not indicated in this scenario unless there is an outbreak of polio- in which case OPV is given to at least 500 children in the vicinity.

 

Vaccine protocol during a disaster & Epidemic:

questions.text: A 45-year-old male undergoes a split-thickness skin graft for a large wound on his leg. Three days postoperatively, the graft appears swollen with fluid accumulating underneath it. Which of the following complications is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hematoma or seroma formation

 

Explanation:

  • In this scenario, the accumulation of fluid beneath the graft is indicative of hematoma or seroma formation.
  • This complication can prevent proper adherence of the graft to the wound bed, leading to graft failure if not addressed promptly.
