  • Hematomas are collections of blood, while seromas are accumulations of clear fluid. Both can occur when there is inadequate hemostasis or when there is excessive movement or pressure on the graft site post-operatively.

 

Complications of Skin Grafting:

  1. Graft Failure (Option A ruled out):
    • This occurs when the graft does not survive or integrate with the recipient site, due to poor vascularization or improper placement.
    • It is not characterized by fluid accumulation beneath the graft.
    • It can be prevented by ensuring good contact between the graft and the wound bed and avoiding movement or pressure on the graft.
  2. Infection (Option C ruled out):
    • Infection typically presents with redness, warmth, and pus rather than just fluid accumulation.
    • Strict sterile techniques during surgery and the use of prophylactic antibiotics can help prevent infections.
  3. Hematoma or Seroma Formation (Option B):
    • Occur when blood or fluid collects under the graft.
    • Proper hemostasis during surgery and the use of drains can prevent this issue.
  4. Poor Cosmetic Outcome (Option D ruled out): 
    • If the graft does not match the recipient site's skin texture or thickness, or if it is not placed correctly, the cosmetic result may be unsatisfactory.
    • Careful selection of graft thickness and meticulous placement can help achieve a better aesthetic outcome.

questions.text: A researcher is investigating the association between a new dietary supplement and the development of a rare type of cancer. The study includes 100 patients with the cancer and 100 healthy individuals. All of the following biases can occur in this type of study except?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Pygmalion Bias
 

Explanation:

Pygmalion Bias occurs when the researcher's expectations influence participant performance. This bias is irrelevant to case-control studies, which are retrospective and observational and more susceptible to biases like recall, selection, and ascertainment bias.

 

Pygmalion Bias/ Rosenthal Effect:

  • A phenomenon where higher researcher expectations increase participant performance or outcomes.
  • Motivation is proportional to performance and gives an exaggerated response.
  • Seen in experimental or educational settings.
  • For example, increased motivation by teachers increases student performance.

 

Recall Bias (Option A) occurs when participants do not accurately remember past events or experiences.

  • It is common in case-control studies where cases might remember exposure more clearly than controls.

 

Selection Bias (Option B)

  • Happens when there is a systematic difference in characteristics between those selected for study and those not.
  • It is possible that the cases and controls are not representative of the general population.

 

Surveillance Bias or Ascertainment bias (Option C)

  • Occurs when the disease or outcome is more likely to be identified in the exposed group because they are more closely monitored.
  • This could occur if cases are more frequently monitored for dietary habits than controls.

questions.text: A 3-year-old unvaccinated child presents with high fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and a maculopapular rash that began on the face and has spread to the trunk and limbs. Oral examination reveals small, white lesions on the buccal mucosa. Which complication is most likely to develop in the acute phase of this illness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pneumonia

 

Explanation:

  • Pneumonia is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in acute measles and is the most likely immediate complication in this case, especially in an unvaccinated child.
  • Measles is an acute, highly contagious viral infection caused by the measles virus, a member of the Paramyxoviridae family.
  • It primarily affects children and is transmitted through respiratory droplets or small-particle aerosols.

 

Clinical Stages of Measles:

Stage

Duration

Symptoms

Incubation Period

10 days (up to 21 days)

Asymptomatic phase; the virus multiplies in the respiratory tract, followed by primary and secondary viremia.

Prodromal Stage

4 days
  • Fever (day 10),
  • Koplik’s spots (day 12),
  • non-specific symptoms (cough, coryza, conjunctivitis).

Eruptive Stage

4 days post fever

The maculopapular rash appears first behind the ears, then spreads to the face, trunk, and limbs, fading in the same order.

Post-measles Stage

Variable

Characterized by weight loss, weakness, and a risk of progressing to chronic conditions.

 

Complications of Measles:

A. Secondary Bacterial Infections

  • Immune suppression following measles increases susceptibility to bacterial infections.
  • Otitis media and bronchopneumonia are the most frequent bacterial complications.
  • Worsening of underlying tuberculosis with a possible false-negative Mantoux test.

 

B. Complications Due to Measles Virus Itself

  • Giant-cell pneumonitis (Hecht’s pneumonia), primarily in immunocompromised and HIV-infected individuals.
  • Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup).
  • Diarrhea leading to malnutrition and vitamin A deficiency.

 

C. Central Nervous System (CNS) Complications

  • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE): A rare but severe late complication characterized by progressive CNS deterioration.
  • Other CNS complications include post-measles encephalomyelitis and measles inclusion body encephalitis.

 

Acute encephalitis (Option A): Occurs in approximately 1 in 1,000 cases, often presenting later with neurological symptoms, not during the acute phase.

 

Otitis media (Option B): It is common but typically less severe than pneumonia in terms of immediate risk.

 

SSPE (Option C): It is a delayed complication, developing years after initial infection, thus not relevant to the acute phase.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presents with symptoms of indigestion and steatorrhea. Laboratory tests suggest decreased bicarbonate secretion from the pancreas. Which Gastrointestinal hormone is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Secretin

Explanation:

  • Secretin is released from the S cells in response to acid and fat in the duodenum and is responsible for bicarbonate secretion in the GIT.
  • Functions:
    • Pepsin secretion - helps in protein digestion (patient is suffering from indigestion because of deficiency of this function)
    • Pancreatic and biliary bicarbonate secretion - neutralises the acid in the duodenum
    • Stimulates hepatic ductal secretion
    • Growth of exocrine pancreas
    • Inhibition of gastrin release and direct gastric acid secretion
    • It also inhibits gastric emptying and small intestinal motility.

Cholecystokinin (Option A): Stimulates pancreatic enzyme secretion and gallbladder contraction but is more related to enzyme secretion, not bicarbonate.

Gastrin(Option B): Stimulates acid secretion by the stomach, not bicarbonate from the pancreas.

Motilin(Option D):: Involved in gastrointestinal motility during fasting, unrelated to bicarbonate secretion or fat digestion.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents with fatigue, muscle weakness, and bone pain for the past several months. She has a history of hypothyroidism and is currently taking levothyroxine. She lives in North India and avoids dairy products. Physical examination reveals mild tenderness over her shins. Laboratory tests reveal:


	
		
			
			Serum calcium
			
			
			8.2 mg/dL (normal range: 8.5-10.5 mg/dL)
			
		
		
			
			Serum phosphorus
			
			
			2.0 mg/dL (normal range: 2.5-4.5 mg/dL)
			
		
		
			
			Parathyroid hormone (PTH)
			
			
			Elevated
			
		
	


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the above scenario, the patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings are most likely to be Vitamin D deficiency.

Blood findings of Vitamin D deficiency

Biochemical Feature

Explanation

Hypocalcemia

Due to decreased calcium absorption in the intestine.

Hypophosphatemia

Due to decreased phosphate absorption in the intestine and decreased reabsorption of phosphate in the kidneys.

Secondary Hyperparathyroidism

In response to low calcium levels, the parathyroid hormone (PTH) increases, which increases calcium reabsorption from bone and the kidneys.

Elevated Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP)

Due to Increased bone turnover as a result of increased PTH.

25-hydroxy cholecalciferol

Decreased.

 

Prolonged secondary hyperparathyroidism can cause renal osteodystrophy, which may lead to pathological fractures.

Primary hyperparathyroidism (Option B) leads to excess PTH production, causing hypercalcemia.

Hypoparathyroidism (Option C) presents with low PTH and hypocalcemia. Hypothyroidism is commonly associated with vitamin D deficiency, potentially due to immune dysfunction and impacts on calcium metabolism

Chronic kidney disease (Option D) causes secondary hyperparathyroidism due to impaired phosphate excretion and low 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D levels, it is typically associated with hyperphosphatemia.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of COPD presents to the clinic for a routine follow-up. He reports experiencing increased shortness of breath and wheezing. He is on albuterol used as needed, and the physician decides to add ipratropium. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the latter?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer : D) M3 receptor antagonist

Explanation:

  • Ipratropium is an anticholinergic agent that works by blocking the M3 receptors on smooth muscle cells in the airways, leading to bronchodilation. It also inhibits the parasympathetic influence, which reduces bronchoconstriction and mucous secretion in the lungs, thereby improving airflow.
     
  • M2 receptors are inhibitory receptors on presynaptic neurons that regulate acetylcholine release. While M2 antagonism can theoretically contribute to increased acetylcholine release, it is not the primary mechanism for ipratropium's therapeutic effect.

 

Mechanism of Action

Drug

Mechanism of Action

Effect

Use

Ipratropium

M3 receptor antagonist

Inhibition of parasympathetic tone, leading to bronchodilation

COPD, asthma (often in combination with β2 agonists)

Albuterol

β2 receptor agonist

Bronchodilation through smooth muscle relaxation

Acute asthma, COPD relief

Tiotropium

M3 receptor antagonist

Longer-acting bronchodilation

COPD, asthma

questions.text: Which of the following conditions will not show the presence of nuclei retained in the stratum corneum as a pathological finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lichen planus

Explanation:

  • Since epidermal turnover is not affected in lichenoid reactions, parakeratosis is not commonly seen in lichen planus. Instead, it is associated with hyperkeratosis, which is the thickening of the stratum corneum.
  • The stratum corneum is the topmost layer of the epidermis, where cells (keratinocytes/corneocytes) have lost the nuclei and cytoplasmic organelles.

Parakeratosis:

  • The retention of nuclei in the keratinocyte of the stratum corneum, known as Parakeratosis, is associated either with increased epidermal cell turnover or with inflammatory changes in the epidermis itself.
  • It is seen in psoriasis, sub-acute eczema, squamous cell carcinoma, and actinic keratoses.
  • Parakeratosis is physiological in oral mucosa and vaginal mucosa.

Both Parakeratosis and Hyperkeratosis are pathological findings that can be seen in the Stratum corneum.

Eczema (Option A): Parakeratosis is seen as a pathological finding in sub-acute eczematous reactions.

 

Psoriasis (Option B): In psoriasis, both parakeratosis and hyperkeratosis can be seen.

 

Bowen’s disease (Option D): Bowen’s disease is an in-situ squamous cell carcinoma of the epidermis. In this condition, nuclei retention (due to incomplete maturation of epidermal keratinocytes) in the stratum corneum can be seen as a pathological finding.

Parakeratosis:

questions.text: Which of the following will have no role in immediate management of acute onset hyperkalemia?

choices.text: 50 ml of 50% dextrose with 10 units of regular insulin

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sodium polystyrene sulfonate:

  • Effect of SPS takes 24 hours to manifest. It also has a rare side effect of colonic perforation. So amongst the options it is best answer due to two reasons : delayed onset of action and unacceptable side effect.
  • Sodium bicarbonate is used only in hyperkalemia with concomitant metabolic acidosis. Effect comes after 4-6 hours.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A and D are standard treatments so are easily ruled out

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is in the post-operative ward after a cesarean section. She had no complications and gave birth to a healthy baby. Which of the following is a prophylactic step she needs to be advised to prevent deep vein thrombosis?

choices.text: Early mobilization along with compression stockings

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Early mobilization along with compression stockings

 

Explanation:

The case scenario here is of an abdominopelvic surgery that needs early mobilization with compression stockings as a prophylaxis for preventing DVT.

In the above scenario, the risk factor for DVT is pregnancy and immediate postpartum, along with having undergone an abdominopelvic surgery which only needs mechanical methods of prophylaxis rather than pharmacological.

 

Risk groups for deep vein thrombosis:

  • Older age groups (>40 yrs)
  • Hospitalized and immobilized patients
  • Pregnancy and the recently postpartum state
  • Those on hormonal replacement therapy
  • Women on oral contraceptive pills
  • Major surgery
  • Long haul travellers (>6hrs)
  • With conditions like:
    • Past venous thromboembolism
    • Malignancies
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Varicose veins
    • Antiphospholipid syndrome
    • Myeloproliferative disorders
    • Polycythemia
    • Obesity

 

Level of risk

Suggested thromboprophylaxis options

Very low-risk

General or abdominopelvic surgery
  • No specific thromboprophylaxis
  • Early ambulation along with compression stockings (Option A)

Low risk

General or abdominopelvic surgery
  • Mechanical prophylaxis
  • Early ambulation and mechanical device (compression stockings)

Moderate risk

General or abdominopelvic surgery
  • LMWH (at recommended doses) (Option B)
  • LDUH (Option C) or mechanical prophylaxis

High bleeding risk
  • Mechanical prophylaxis
  • Early ambulation and mechanical device( compression stockings

High risk

General or abdominopelvic surgery
  • LMWH (at recommended doses),
  • fondaparinux (Option D), and mechanical prophylaxis

High bleeding risk

General or abdominopelvic surgery for cancer
  • Mechanical thromboprophylaxis
  • Extended-duration LMWH (4 weeks)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs), persistent back pain, and hematuria. Imaging reveals a large, branched stone occupying a significant portion of her right kidney. Urinalysis shows alkaline pH, the presence of bacteria, and crystals as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely composition of this stone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Struvite

Explanation:

  • Struvite (Magnesium Ammonium Phosphate):
  • Found only in alkaline urine.
  • Appears as coffin-lid-shaped crystals and is always associated with urinary infections.

Calcium Oxalate (Option A ruled out):

  • Shapes include envelopes, spindles, ovals, octahedral, picket fences, or dumbbell-shaped.
  • Often feature an "X" in the center.

Calcium Phosphate:

  • Colorless crystals that appear as plates, stars, stellate shapes, or clusters of needles or rosettes.
  • Typically found in more alkaline urine.

Cystine (Option D ruled out):

  • Crystals are hexagonal in shape and resemble nearly perfect benzene rings under the microscope.

Uric Acid (Option B ruled out):

  • Crystals can be rhomboidal-shaped, rosettes, or plates.
  • Found in acidic urine with a pH of 5.5 or lower.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy with infantile spasms has been treated for 6 months, showing improved seizure control. The neurologist is concerned about the potential for permanent peripheral visual field defects with long-term use of his current medication. Which antiepileptic drug is most likely to cause these visual field defects, requiring regular ophthalmologic monitoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vigabatrin

Explanation:

  • Vigabatrin is an antiepileptic drug used for infantile spasms and refractory complex partial seizures. It acts by irreversibly inhibiting GABA transaminase to increase GABA levels in the brain.
  • Vigabatrin is associated with a significant risk of permanent peripheral visual field defects and retinal toxicity, necessitating regular ophthalmologic monitoring to detect and manage potential visual impairments early.
  • Carbamazepine (Option A) and Valproic acid (Option B) can cause a few ophthalmic side effects, including visual disturbances such as diplopia and blurred vision, but not associated with permanent visual loss.

Among the given options, Levetiracetam (Option D) is considered to have a favourable safety profile with minimal ophthalmic side effects.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with 3 days of high fever, headache, and joint pain. Examination reveals a maculopapular rash and a positive tourniquet test. Labs show leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and mildly elevated liver enzymes. What is the most appropriate next step for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rapid antigen detection test

Explanation:

A rapid antigen detection test (NS1) is used to diagnose dengue fever within 5 days of onset of fever. Dengue presents with high fever, severe headache, joint pain (breakbone fever), rash, and a positive tourniquet test. Laboratory findings often show leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes.

Blood culture (Option B) is not used to diagnose dengue fever, as it is a viral infection, not bacterial.

PCR for malaria (Option C) parasites is used to diagnose malaria. The patient presents with a shorter-duration fever and hepatosplenomegaly, not with a positive tourniquet test.

IgM ELISA (Option D) is used to diagnose dengue after >5 days of symptoms.

questions.text: After a fall from a height with undue arm abduction, the patient presented as shown. Mark the wrong statement about this condition.

choices.text: Complete clawing of hand is seen
Associated horner syndrome can be seen
Due to injury to lower trunk of brachial plexus

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) C7,C8 & T1 are affected

 

Explanation:

Given clinical scenario is suggestive of Klumpke’s paralysis secondary to fall with abduction of arm causing injury to C8 and T1 nerve roots resulting in complete clawing of hand.

 

Erb’s Paralysis & Klumpke’s Paralysis:

Feature

Erb’s Paralysis

Klumpke’s Paralysis

Site of Injury
  • Upper trunk of the brachial plexus (Erb’s point)
  • Lower trunk of the brachial plexus (Option D)

Causes of Injury
  • Undue separation of head from the shoulder
  • Birth injury/difficult childbirth
  • During anesthesia
  • Undue abduction of the arm
  • Birth injury

Nerve Roots Involved
  • Mainly C5, partly C6
  • Mainly T1, partly C8 (Option A)

Muscles Paralyzed
  • Biceps brachii
  • Deltoid
  • Brachialis
  • Brachioradialis
  • Partly supraspinatus, infraspinatus, supinator
  • Intrinsic muscles of the hand (T1)
  • Ulnar flexors of the wrist and fingers (C8)

Deformity and Position
  • Arm: Hangs by the side, adducted and medially rotated
  • Forearm: Extended and pronated (Waiter’s tip position)
  • Also known as Policeman tip deformity

 
  • Complete clawing of hand due to hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the interphalangeal joints. (Option B)

Additional Features
  • Sensory loss over lower deltoid.
  • Bird winging effect of scapula.
  • Horner’s syndrome (Option C) if T1 is injured.
  • Vasomotor and trophic changes
  • Cutaneous anesthesia along the ulnar border of the forearm and hand.

questions.text: A 27-week gestational-age preterm infant in the NICU experiences persistent apnea lasting over 20 seconds despite gentle tactile stimulation and supplemental oxygen. Nasal continuous positive airway pressure (nCPAP) has been used but has not resolved the episodes. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Continue nasal continuous positive airway pressure (nCPAP)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Administer intravenous caffeine citrate

 

Explanation:

  • Caffeine is the treatment of choice for recurrent or persistent apnea of prematurity that does not respond to initial measures like tactile stimulation or nCPAP.
  • It increases central respiratory drive, lowers the threshold for response to hypercapnia, enhances diaphragmatic contractility, and prevents diaphragmatic fatigue.

 

Management of Apnea of Prematurity:

  • For mild and intermittent episodes: Gentle tactile stimulation or provision of supplemental oxygen by nasal cannula is often sufficient.
  • If apnea episodes are more frequent or prolonged, nasal continuous positive airway pressure (nCPAP) or heated humidified high-flow nasal cannula (HHHFNC) can be used to maintain airway patency.
  • For recurrent or persistent apnea:
    • Methylxanthines (e.g., caffeine) are preferred because they effectively stimulate respiratory drive and reduce the incidence and severity of apnea.
    • Caffeine aids in extubation and lowers Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) risk with fewer side effects than theophylline.
    • It is safe for oral or intravenous use with a wide therapeutic window and minimal need for serum monitoring.

 

Continuing nCPAP (Option A) is beneficial for managing obstructive or mixed apnea by maintaining airway patency but is less effective for central apnea. Since the apnea persists despite nCPAP, additional pharmacological intervention is needed.

 

Initiate doxapram infusion (Option C): Doxapram is a respiratory stimulant but is less commonly used due to side effects and is typically considered only if methylxanthines are ineffective.

 

Start low-dose theophylline (Option D): Theophylline is another methylxanthine but is less preferred than caffeine due to a shorter half-life and higher risk of side effects d/t narrow therapeutic range (5-15 microgram), such as tachycardia and feeding intolerance.

questions.text: A 37 year old woman presents for routine checkup with an ultrasound revealing a 3 cm asymptomatic endometrioma on the left ovary. She expresses that she does not wish to conceive in the future. She has regular cycles, with normal flow & mild spasmodic dysmenorrhea. Given the clinical scenario, what is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient's endometrioma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Follow-up 6 monthly with transvaginal ultrasound

Explanation:

In this scenario, the patient has a 3 cm asymptomatic endometrioma and does not desire future fertility. According to current guidelines, Follow-up 6 monthly with transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) is the most appropriate management for endometrioma as surgical interventions are indicated only for cysts> 5cm.

Management of Endometrioma:

  • If the patient wants to conceive:
    • Expectant management is done, irrespective of the size of the endometrioma
  • If pregnancy is not desired:
    • Size < 5cm and Asymptomatic: Follow up six monthly / 1 yearly with TVS
    • Size >5cm: Laparoscopic cystectomy (Option A)
  • Total Abdominal Hysterectomy (Option B):
    • Done only in women > 40 years after completion of family.
    • Prevents the formation of new lesions and pain due to it.
  • Laparoscopy procedures include:
    • Adhesiolysis
    • Fulgration of implants
    • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA)
  • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA) (Option C): It involves disrupting nerve pathways to alleviate pain associated with endometriosis, particularly pelvic pain. It is not indicated for the management of ovarian endometriomas.
  • After surgical procedures, patients require medical management
    • Adolescents <16 years: OCPs
    • Adolescents >16 years: OCPs / GnRH Agonists
    • Adults: OCPs / GnRH Agonists / Progesterone

questions.text: What is the type of torture mentioned in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Belana

 

Explanation:

The given image depicts Belana

 

Torture: Defined as deliberate, systemic or wanton infliction of physical or mental suffering by one or more persons acting alone or on the orders of any authority to force another person to yield information or for any other reason.

 

Physical torture subtypes

Types of torture

Description

Belana or The roller

(Option B)
  • The pole is placed on the back of the victim and is pressed down with great weight and then rolled up over the legs and the body.
  • Crushing of soft tissue and damage to muscles of the legs and the body.

Chepuwa

(Option A)
  • The thighs of the victim are placed under two wooden rods and pressed to induce severe pain.

Sawhorse or ‘el cabellete’

(Option C)
  • Forced straddling on a sharp object like a saw.
  • Perineal bruising was seen.

Operating table or ‘el quirofano’

(Option D)
  • Beating on the abdomen while lying on a table with the upper half of the body unsupported.
  • Bruise, ruptured abdominal viscera.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male reports a gradual decrease in vision in his left eye over the past two months, describing it as a "dimming" rather than a complete loss. He also has difficulty reading and seeing clearly. As per the image below, which test is most likely being conducted?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Swinging flashlight test

 

Explanation:

  • The above given scenario is suspective of optic nerve dysfunction and the image depicted above is describing RAPD (Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect) which is tested by swinging flashlight test.

 

Swinging flashlight test:

  • The swinging flashlight test is used to detect a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), often seen with unilateral optic nerve lesions, even when visual acuity is normal.

 

Procedure:

  1. Shine a bright flashlight on one pupil and observe its constriction.
  2. Quickly move the light to the contralateral pupil and observe the response.
  3. Repeat the process several times, alternating between the two eyes.


 

  • Normal response: Both pupils constrict equally, and the pupil receiving the light remains tightly constricted.
  • Abnormal response (RAPD): If there is a relative afferent pathway defect, the affected pupil will dilate when the light is moved from the normal eye to the abnormal eye.
  • Significance: The presence of Marcus Gunn pupil (RAPD) is an early indication of optic nerve disease, even when visual acuity appears normal.

 

Causes:

 

  • Optic neuritis
  • Optic neuropathy
  • Chiasmal compression
  • Intraocular hemorrhage
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Retinal detachment
  • Optic tract lesion
  • Central or branch arterial occlusion
  • Central or branch vein occlusion
  • Anisometropic amblyopia
  • Cataract
  • Corneal scar
  • Visual pathway damage



 

Perimetry (Option B) measures and maps the visual field, assessing peripheral vision to detect defects or abnormalities.

  • It aids in diagnosing eye conditions like glaucoma, retinal diseases, and neurological disorders affecting visual pathways.

 

Tonometry (Option C) is a diagnostic test used in Glaucoma to measure intraocular pressure (IOP).

 

The visual acuity test (Option D) measures the sharpness or clarity of a person's vision.

  • It evaluates how well a person can see details at a specific distance, typically assessing the ability to read letters or symbols on Snellen’s chart.

questions.text: A 25-year-old runner presents with pain along the front part of his right leg and difficulty in lifting the foot upwards after increasing his training intensity. O/E, he shows weakness in extending the big toe and foot drop. Which muscle is most likely affected in this patient, leading to his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Extensor Hallucis Longus

 

Explanation:

The patient presents with difficulty in dorsiflexing the foot and weakness in extending the big toe, which is primarily the function of the extensor hallucis longus.

 

Anterior compartment of the leg

Muscles

Attachments

Innervation

Action

Clinical aspects

Tibialis Anterior
  • Lateral condyle, proximal 1/2-2/3 lateral tibial shaft, interosseous membrane.
  • Inserts onto medial cuneiform and base of 1st metatarsal.

Deep fibular nerve (L4, L5)
  • Dorsiflexes foot
  • Inverts foot
  • Supports medial arch
  • Weakness: foot drop
  • Can cause shin splints.

Extensor Hallucis Longus
  • The middle half of the medial fibula and interosseous membrane.
  • Inserts onto the dorsal base of the distal phalanx of the hallux.

Deep fibular nerve (L5)
  • Extends hallux
  • Dorsiflexes foot
  • Weakness: Difficulty extending the big toe.

Extensor Digitorum Longus
  • Lateral tibial condyle, proximal 3/4 medial fibula, interosseous membrane.
  • Tendons insert onto middle and distal phalanges of lateral 4 toes.

Deep fibular nerve (L5, S1)
  • Extends lateral 4 toes
  • Dorsiflexes foot
  • Weakness: Issues extending toes
  • Foot drop risk

Fibularis Tertius
  • Distal 1/3 medial fibula, interosseous membrane.
  • Inserts onto the base of the 5th metatarsal.

Deep fibular nerve (L5, S1)
  • Dorsiflexes foot
  • Everts the foot
  • Absent in some individuals
  • Helps prevent foot drag in gait.

 

Tibialis Anterior (Option A): While it contributes to dorsiflexion, the primary symptom of difficulty extending the big toe suggests the involvement of extensor hallucis longus.

Extensor Digitorum Longus (Option C): Although it extends the lateral toes, it does not directly affect the movements of the big toe.

Fibularis Tertius (Option D): This muscle aids in dorsiflexion and eversion but is less likely to cause difficulty in extending the big toe specifically.

Reference:

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with diphtheria. The child's parent, who is unvaccinated and asymptomatic, is identified as a close contact. What is the MOST appropriate management for the parent?

choices.text: Administer a single booster dose of diphtheria toxoid.
Administer diphtheria antitoxin (DAT) and complete the diphtheria toxoid series.
Administer prophylactic penicillin or erythromycin only.
No action is needed since the parent is asymptomatic.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Administer diphtheria antitoxin (DAT) and complete the diphtheria toxoid series.

Explanation:

For Unvaccinated close contacts, administer diphtheria antitoxin (DAT) for immediate passive immunity, complete the diphtheria toxoid series for long-term active immunity and prophylactic antibiotics (it is given to all the contacts).

Management of diphtheria contacts:

Diphtheria Contact

Management

All Contacts

(Option C)
  • Assess for signs and symptoms of diphtheria.
  • Obtain a sample for Corynebacterium diphtheriae culture.
  • Administer prophylactic antibiotics: Penicillin or erythromycin for 7-10 days, stopping if culture results are negative.

Unvaccinated close contact

(Option B)

Administer diphtheria antitoxin (DAT) for immediate passive immunity. Complete the diphtheria toxoid series for long-term active immunity.

Unknown vaccination status or received <3 doses

Complete the diphtheria toxoid series: This includes 3 primary and 2 booster doses.

Received >3 doses, and the last dose was >5 years ago

(Option A)

Administer a single diphtheria toxoid booster dose

Received >3 doses, and the last dose was <5 years ago

The contact should receive the next dose of diphtheria toxoid according to the recommended schedule without needing an additional dose due to the current exposure.

 

Option D: Even though the parent is asymptomatic, they are at high risk of developing diphtheria, given their unvaccinated status.

questions.text: A medical intern sustains a needle-stick injury from a known HIV-positive patient. What is the ideal time frame to initiate post-exposure prophylaxis for maximum efficacy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Within 2 hours 

 

Explanation:

Post-exposure prophylaxis for HIV should be started as early as possible preferably within 2 hours. It is not effective after 72 hours. Drugs used are tenofovir, lamivudine and dolutregavir for 4 weeks. Waiting for test results or seroconversion is incorrect and delays treatment.

questions.text:
Arrange the steps of labour in the correct sequence.

 


	Descent
	Flexion
	Engagement
	Internal rotation
	Delivery of posterior shoulder
	Extension
	External rotation
	Delivery of anterior shoulder
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A

 

Explanation:

 

Normal labour:

 

Series of events that take place in the genital organs in an effort to expel the viable products of conception (fetus, placenta and the membranes) out of the womb through the vagina. The steps in normal labour include:

 

Engagement (widest part of the fetal head enters the pelvic inlet).

↓

Descent (fetal head moves downward into the pelvis).

↓

Flexion (fetal head bends forward so the smallest diameter enters the pelvis).

↓

Internal rotation (fetal head rotates to align with the maternal pelvis).

↓

Extension (fetal head extends as it passes under the pubic symphysis).

↓

Restitution (passive head movement due to neck untwisting during internal rotation).

↓

External rotation (fetal head rotates externally to align with the shoulders).

↓

Delivery of the anterior shoulder followed by the posterior shoulder of the fetus.

↓

Expulsion (rest of the body is delivered)

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a typical feature of the triple deformity in tuberculosis of the knee?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lateral displacement of the patella

 

Explanation:

 

Lateral displacement of the patella is not a typical feature of the triple deformity; the primary features involve changes in the tibia and knee flexion rather than patellar positioning.

 

TB knee stages

 

1. Synovitis
  • Boggy swelling

2. Early Arthritis
  • Severe pain and swelling.

3. Late Arthritis/Pathological dislocation
  • Triple deformity (Options A, C, and D)
    • Posterior subluxation of the tibia (due to laxity of the capsule)
    • External or lateral rotation of the tibia (due to spasm of the iliotibial band)
    • Flexion of the knee (due to spasms of the hamstrings)

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presents with delayed puberty. Physical examination reveals small testicular volume and a lack of secondary sexual characteristics. Hormonal tests indicate low testosterone levels but elevated FSH levels. Which of the following functions of Sertoli cells is most likely compromised in this patient?

choices.text: Secretion of testosterone in response to LH stimulation
Production of inhibin, leading to increased FSH levels
Conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone by 5α-reductase
Support of spermatogenesis through FSH-mediated stimulation

questions.solution:
Answer: D) Support of spermatogenesis through FSH-mediated stimulation

 

Explanation:

The most plausible explanation for the observed hormonal imbalances and clinical features is a compromised ability of Sertoli cells to respond to FSH stimulation, leading to both impaired spermatogenesis and, consequently, low testosterone levels. The reduced negative feedback from inhibin due to impaired Sertoli cell function further contributes to the elevated FSH levels.

 

Hormones of Spermatogenesis:

Follicular stimulating hormone:

  • FSH is essential for the initial development of spermatogonia cells.
  • Main targets of FSH action include:
    • Proliferation of Sertoli cell
    • Proliferation of Spermatogonia up to primary spermatocyte stage
    • Support the process of meiosis.

Testosterone:

  • Testosterone is particularly required for the terminal stages of spermatogenesis
  • Main targets of testosterone action include:
    • Spermiogenesis (spermatid to mature sperm)
    • Spermiation (release of sperm)
    • Meiosis (suppression of testosterone leads to block in meiosis)

Estrogen:

  • Main targets of Estrogen include:
    • Fluid resorption and concentration of sperm
    • Acrosome biogenesis of sperm

Growth hormone:

  • Growth hormone specifically promotes early division of the spermatogonia

 

Option A) Secretion of testosterone in response to LH stimulation is a function of Leydig cell

Option B) Production of inhibin leading to increased FSH levels simply does not explain the low testosterone levels seen in this patient

Option C) While testosterone does play a role in spermatogenesis, its production is mainly stimulated by LH acting on Leydig cells.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of aortic stenosis, hypertension, and recent cerebral venous thrombosis on anticoagulant therapy is scheduled for lower limb surgery. The anesthesiology team is evaluating the use of spinal anaesthesia. Which of the following is not a contraindication for spinal anaesthesia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypertension

 

Explanation:

 

  • Hypertension is not a contraindication for spinal anaesthesia.
  • Spinal anaesthesia can be safely used in patients with well-controlled hypertension.
  • It is essential to monitor blood pressure closely during and after the procedure, as spinal anaesthesia can cause hypotension due to sympathetic blockade.

Contraindications of Spinal Anesthesia

Absolute Contraindications
  • Patient refusal
  • Localized sepsis
  • Allergy to planned medications
  • Patient's inability to remain still
  • Raised intracranial pressure (ICP)

Relative Contraindications
  • Myelopathy or Peripheral Neuropathy
  • Spinal Stenosis
  • Previous spine surgery
  • Neural Tube Defects
  • Inherited Coagulopathy
  • System infections
  • Cardiac valvular stenosis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Anticoagulant medication

Aortic stenosis (Option A) decreases the heart’s ability to maintain adequate blood flow. The sudden drop in blood pressure from spinal anaesthesia could lead to dangerously low coronary perfusion and cardiac ischemia.

Cerebral venous thrombosis (Option B), combined with anticoagulant therapy, is a contraindication for spinal anaesthesia due to the risk of elevated intracranial pressure and bleeding complications.

Vertebral osteomyelitis (Option C): Introducing a needle into an infected area carries a high risk of spreading the infection to the spinal canal, potentially leading to meningitis or epidural abscess.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient has been experiencing nasal congestion, facial pain, and nasal discharge for one week. Examination reveals maxillary sinus tenderness and nasal obstruction. The patient reports similar episodes resolving within 10-14 days. What is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Viral infection

Explanation:

The symptoms suggest acute sinusitis, most commonly caused by a viral infection from upper respiratory viruses like rhinovirus, influenza, or parainfluenza.

Allergic fungal sinusitis (Option B) is typically associated with chronic sinusitis, not acute episodes, and is more common in patients with atopy or asthma.

Chronic Sinusitis is defined as inflammation of the sinuses and nasal passages lasting more than 12 weeks despite medical treatment. It is characterised by symptoms such as nasal obstruction, facial pain or pressure, nasal discharge, and a reduction in the sense of smell.

 

Causes of Chronic Sinusitis

Category

Contributing Factors

Patient Factors

Anatomic structural deformities: Obstruction of sinus ostia (e.g., deviated septum, concha bullosa, anatomical variations) (Option A)

Lifestyle factors: Smoking, snuff dipping, prolonged use of intranasal medications

Immune Deficiency

Primary: IgG deficiency, primary ciliary dyskinesia, cystic fibrosis

Acquired: HIV, prolonged steroid use, chemotherapy, immunosuppressants in organ transplant patients, leukaemia

Aspirin Sensitivity

Sensitivity to aspirin causing chronic airway inflammation. (Option D)

Environmental Factors

Aeroallergens: Allergic rhinitis, asthma, exposure to allergens (dust, pollen, moulds)

Toxins and Chemicals: Exposure to pollution, occupational chemicals, and toxic gases.

Pathogens

Bacteria (aerobic and anaerobic), fungi, mycobacteria

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient presents with cough, fever, and pleuritic chest pain. A contrast CT is taken and shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Empyema

Explanation:

Clinical symptoms, including cough, fever, and pleuritic chest pain, along with the CT finding of a low-attenuating pleural fluid collection between the enhancing visceral (white arrow) and parietal pleura (black arrow), i.e., Split-pleura sign, confirms the diagnosis of Empyema.

 

Image

 

Lobar pneumonia (Option A) typically shows consolidation.

 

Lung Abscess (Option D) typically appears as a localized, well-defined mass with an air-fluid level within the lung parenchyma rather than in the pleural space.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with chronic jaundice and mild abdominal discomfort. Examination revealed hepatomegaly. Lab tests indicate elevated levels of direct bilirubin. Upon liver biopsy, a pigmented liver is observed. What is the most likely underlying mechanism for these clinical and pathological findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) MRP2 (Multidrug resistance-associated protein 2) defect

 

Explanation:

The clinical and pathological findings are consistent with Dubin-Johnson syndrome, which is characterised by impaired excretion of conjugated bilirubin into bile due to a defect in the MRP2 transporter leading to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

The characteristic pigmented liver is due to the accumulation of epinephrine metabolite (not bilirubin).


 

Type of hyperbilirubinemia

Disorder

Defect

Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia 

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1

Complete deficiency of UGT. (Option A)

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 2

Partial deficiency of UGT.

Gilbert syndrome

Very mild deficiency of UGT.

Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Dubin Johnson syndrome

Defect in canalicular MRP2 protein. (Option C)

 

Pigmented liver (due to epinephrine metabolite)

Rotor syndrome

Defect in ATPs (decreased biliary excretion)

 

Non-pigmented liver

questions.text:

questions.text: A patient with anaemia has elevated levels of 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) in their red blood cells. How does this increased 2,3-BPG level affect the patient’s haemoglobin in terms of oxygen delivery?

choices.text: Forms salt bridges with positively charged residues forming a relaxed structure
Disrupts salt bridges formed in the taut structure, decreasing oxygen affinity
Forms salt bridges with positively charged residues stabilising taut structure
Binds to the heme directly, decreasing the oxygen affinity

questions.solution:
• Increased levels of 2,3-BPG stabilise the taut (T) structure of haemoglobin by forming salt bridges with positively charged residues.
  • This stabilisation lowers haemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, promoting oxygen release to tissues, which can be beneficial in conditions like anaemia.

Effect of 2,3 BPG on Hb:

  • Reduces the affinity of Hb for oxygen and helps unload oxygen to tissues.
  • A by-product of glycolysis. (Rapaport Leubering Cycle)

Mechanism:

2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) binds with a pocket formed by the β chains in the deoxygenated state of hemoglobin.

Forms salt bridges with positively charged residues forming a relaxed structure (Option A): Incorrect because salt bridges stabilize the T form, not the R form.

Disrupts salt bridges formed in the taut structure, decreasing oxygen affinity (Option B): Incorrect because 2,3-BPG forms rather than disrupts salt bridges, stabilizing the T form.

Binds to the heme directly, decreasing the oxygen affinity (Option D): Incorrect because 2,3-BPG does not bind to heme; it binds between β-chains in deoxygenated Hb.

questions.text: A 32-year-old mountain climber presents to the base camp complaining of severe headache, nausea, and fatigue after ascending rapidly to a high altitude. On examination, his respiratory rate is increased, and arterial blood gas analysis shows decreased PaCO2. Given the Acute Mountain Sickness (AMS) suspicion, acetazolamide is administered to alleviate symptoms. Which of the following best describes acetazolamide's primary mechanism of action in treating AMS?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Metabolic acidosis

Explanation:

  • Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used to counter the respiratory alkalosis triggred in AMS by inducing metabolic acidosis. 
     

 

 

Mechanism and effects in AMS:
 

Parameter

Change

High altitude effect

↓ PaO₂ → ↑ ventilation → ↓ PaCO₂ → Respiratory alkalosis

Acetazolamide effect

Inhibits carbonic anhydrase → ↑ HCO₃⁻ excretion

Acid–base result

Metabolic acidosis

Clinical outcome

Stimulates respiration, ↓ AMS symptoms

 

Respiratory Alkalosis (Option B): Incorrect because this is the initial disturbance at high altitude due to hyperventilation—not the result of acetazolamide therapy.
 

Respiratory Acidosis (Option C): Incorrect because acetazolamide does not impair ventilation or gas exchange; it does not increase PaCO₂.
 

Metabolic Alkalosis (Option D): Incorrect because acetazolamide causes loss of bicarbonate, resulting in metabolic acidosis, not alkalosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old student presents with a 10-day history of dry cough, mild fever, and fatigue, but has been able to attend daily activities. Chest X-ray shows patchy infiltrates and a physical exam reveals mild crackles. Which of the following is the LEAST likely causative agent of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Atypical pneumonia or walking pneumonia due to the mild symptoms and the ability to continue daily activities despite the infection. Klebsiella pneumoniae is least likely as it typically causes more severe, hospital-acquired pneumonia, unlike the mild presentation of walking pneumonia.

Atypical Pneumonia (Walking Pneumonia)

  • Definition: Atypical pneumonia is a milder form of pneumonia, often caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae, certain viruses, or moulds.
  • Symptoms: Common symptoms include cough, fever, chest pain, headache, and chills, resembling a bad cold.
  • It is generally mild, not requiring bed rest or hospitalization, allowing people to continue daily activities—hence the term "walking pneumonia."
  • Etiologic Agents: Atypical pneumonia is caused by organisms that don't grow on standard cultures or appear on Gram stain, such as:
    • Mycoplasma pneumonia (Option A ruled out)
    • Chlamydia pneumoniae (Option B ruled out)
    • Legionella species (Option C ruled out)
    • Respiratory viruses: Influenza, adenoviruses, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), human metapneumoviruses, and coronaviruses (e.g., SARS-CoV-2)
  • Prevalence: Cases of atypical pneumonia are increasing, particularly among young adults.
  • Diagnosis: These pathogens cannot be cultured in the usual ways, making diagnosis more complex. PCR and other molecular methods are often necessary for confirmation.
  • Treatment: Atypical organisms are resistant to β-lactams (e.g., penicillins) and require treatment with macrolides, fluoroquinolones, or tetracyclines.

questions.text: You are examining an LGA neonate who presents with the physical finding shown in the image below. Given this finding, you suspect the neonate might have an associated congenital heart anomaly. What is the most common congenital heart anomaly you would suspect in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)

 

Explanation:

 

A hairy pinna points to the diagnosis of an infant of a diabetic mother, and the most common congenital heart disease in IDM is ventricular septal defect (VSD)

 

Infant of a diabetic mother:

  • Diabetes is one of the most common endocrine disorders affecting women during pregnancy.
  • Infants of diabetic mothers (IDM) have a higher incidence of congenital malformations, estimated to be between 2.5 and 12%, with an excess of cardiac problems.
  • Pathogenesis:

 

  • Problems in IDM:

 

Macrosomia/Large for Date Baby
  • Increased risk of birth trauma if forceps are used in obstructed labor.
  • Increased chances of perinatal asphyxia in prolonged labor.

Metabolic
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Polycythemia
  • Neonatal jaundice

CVS
  • The most common congenital abnormality in infants of diabetic mothers (IDM) is congenital heart disease (CHD).
  • The most common congenital heart disease in IDM is ventricular septal defect (VSD). (Option C)
  • The most specific congenital heart disease in IDM is transposition of the great arteries (TGA).

Respiratory System
  • Respiratory distress syndrome or Hyaline membrane disease due to delayed maturation of surfactant.

CNS
  • Most common congenital neurologic abnormality in IDM: Neural tube defects.
  • Most specific neurologic abnormality in IDM: Sacral agenesis or caudal regression syndrome.

Renal
  • Renal vein thrombosis
  • Renal agenesis
  • Duplication of ureter
  • Hydroureteronephrosis

GI
  • Duodenal atresia
  • Lazy/small left colon syndrome

Long Term Problems
  • Blindness
  • Obesity
  • Nonketotic hypoglycemia
  • Deafness

1- Liver

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient with diabetes presents with rapidly worsening vision. Upon examination, the ophthalmologist notes the presence of bilateral, snowflake-like white opacities in the cortex of the lens. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Diabetic cataract

 

Explanation:

Diabetic cataract (aka Presenile cataract) is characterized by bilateral, snowflake-like white opacities in the lens cortex, typically seen in young adults with diabetes. Opacities may either resolve spontaneously or progress to maturity within days.

 

  • Senile cataract (Option A) typically affects older individuals, although it can occur earlier in diabetics; however, it does not present with snowflake-like opacities.
  • Christmas tree cataract (Option B) is associated with myotonic dystrophy, not diabetes.
  • Posterior subcapsular cataract (Option D) can be seen in various conditions, including myotonic dystrophy, but does not present with the snowflake-like opacity as seen in true diabetic cataract.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about ketamine is not true in the context of its pharmacological properties and clinical use?

choices.text: It primarily acts as an antagonist at N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors, inducing dissociative anesthesia.
The S(+) isomer is less potent as an analgesic than the R(-) isomer.
It has high lipid solubility, allowing for rapid brain uptake.
It is metabolized in the liver, and its elimination half-life is approximately 2 hours.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) The S(+) isomer is less potent as an analgesic compared to the R(-) isomer.

Explanation:

The S(+) isomer of ketamine is more potent as an analgesic than the R(-) isomer.

Mechanisms of Action

  • Inhibits N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor (NMDA) receptors (Option A), affecting the CNS.
  • Induces dissociative anesthesia, making patients appear conscious but unable to process sensory input.
  • Influences endogenous analgesic pathways.
  • It is an analog of phencyclidine.
  • It is a racemic mixture of R(-) ketamine and S(+) ketamine.
  • Molecular weight: 238 kD
  • High lipid solubility (5 to 10 times that of thiopental) (Option C) and low protein binding (12%).
  • S(+) isomer (Ketanest) is 3 to 4 times more potent as an analgesic with fewer psychomimetic effects.
  • S(+) ketamine causes cognitive impairment and reduced reaction time despite its analgesic properties.
  • S(+) isomer has higher NMDA affinity and potency.

Pharmacokinetics

  • Absorption: Primarily given intravenously or intramuscularly; peak levels in 10-15 minutes.
  • Distribution: Highly lipid-soluble; rapid brain uptake with a 10-15 minute distribution half-life.
  • Biotransformation: Metabolized in the liver to active metabolites; tolerance develops with repeated use. (Option D)
  • Excretion: Renally excreted; elimination half-life of about 2 hours.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with jaundice, fatigue, and nausea after returning from a trip to a rural area in India. Laboratory findings reveal elevated serum bilirubin, ALT, and AST. Which of the following can be used for a definitive detection of the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) HEV PCR for viral RNA

 

Explanation: The symptoms of the patient correlate with the diagnosis of hepatitis E, which can definitively be detected using a polymerase chain reaction to detect the genome (RNA) of the virus.



 

Hepatitis E Virus (HEV)

Epidemiology:

  • Hepatitis E virus is a zoonotic pathogen that can infect several animals, including monkeys, cats, pigs, and dogs.
  • Most non-A, non-B (NANB) hepatitis cases are transmitted through fecal contamination of drinking water (referred to as enterically transmitted NANB or E-NANB).
  • Epidemics are common and hence are also called epidemic NANB.
  •  
  • In India, HEV infection is responsible for the majority of sporadic acute hepatitis cases and epidemic hepatitis, accounting for 30-60% of occurrences.
  • Young adults aged 20 to 40 are more commonly affected by HEV infection than children are by HAV infection.
  • Transmission:
  • Infection sources include fecally contaminated water and the environment.
  • The secondary attack rate (transmission from infected persons to their close contacts) among household contacts is low (2-3%), compared to 10-20% for hepatitis A.

 

Morphology:

  • HEV is a spherical, non-enveloped virus measuring 32-34 nm in diameter and featuring a single-stranded RNA genome.
  • The virion surface has indentations and spikes, and the virus is labile.
  • It has a specific antigen, HEV-Ag.
  • It is morphologically similar to Caliciviruses, such as the Norwalk virus, which is classified provisionally in the Hepeviridae family.


 

Clinical features:

  • Incubation period:
    • Ranges from 2 to 9 weeks, averaging around six weeks.
  • Affected population:
    • Primarily young to middle-aged adults (ages 15-40).
  • Severity:
    • Generally mild and self-limited, with a low case fatality rate of about 1%.
  • Pregnant women:
    • Higher risk, with a 20-40% case fatality rate in the last trimester.
    • Fulminant hepatitis can occur at a significantly higher risk, with a rate of around 20%.
  • There is no chronic infection or carrier state associated with this condition.

 

Laboratory diagnosis:

  • HEV RNA can be identified in stool and serum using reverse transcriptase PCR, even before clinical symptoms appear.
  • Serum Antibody Detection by ELISA:
    • IgM anti-HEV: Appears in serum simultaneously with elevated liver enzyme levels, indicating an acute infection.
    • IgG anti-HEV: Replaces IgM within 2 to 4 weeks after symptoms resolve and can persist for years, indicating recovery or a past infection.
    • ELISA kits are available for detecting IgG and IgM antibodies using recombinant and synthetic peptide antigens.
    • These have a high rate of false negatives and positives and hence cannot be used as a definitive method. (Options A & B)
  • HEV virions can be detected through immuno-electron microscopy (IEM) of bile, serum, and feces during the incubation or acute phase.
    • This is not a feasible or easily accessible method and hence, cannot be done in an acute setup. (Options C)


 

Treatment:

  • There are no specific antivirals against it and only supportive therapy is necessary.

 

Prevention:

  • China has developed and licensed the first hepatitis E vaccine, known as ‘HEV 239,’ based on recombinant HEV proteins.
  • It is not available worldwide yet.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with severe abdominal pain and inability to urinate after a car accident. On examination, he has diffuse abdominal tenderness with guarding and rigidity. A cystogram reveals urine leakage into the peritoneal cavity. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Emergency laparotomy

 

Explanation:

  • In the above clinical scenario, the patient presents with signs and symptoms of intraperitoneal bladder rupture, which is a surgical emergency.
  • Therefore, emergency laparotomy is done immediately.

 

Intraperitoneal rupture

  • Involves a tear or injury to the peritoneum over the bladder, and urine leaks into the peritoneal cavity in males.
  • Causes: Often occurs in a fully distended bladder, usually due to trauma or injury.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Sudden, severe pain in the suprapubic region.
    • Signs of shock and syncope.
    • Diffuse abdominal pain with later features of peritonitis.
    • Abdominal distension.
    • Haematuria
    • Absence of desire to urinate.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Plain X-ray: May show ground glass appearance.
    • Peritoneal Tap: Used to collect urine from the abdominal cavity.
    • Cystography: Iodine dye is injected via a catheter to visualize bladder tears and the dye entry into the peritoneal cavity. The contrast outlines the bowel loops.
    • Ultrasound: To assess other abdominal injuries.
  • Treatment:
    • Emergency Laparotomy is required. (Option B).
    • Bladder tear is sutured with polylactic acid (vicryl) in two layers.
    • Peritoneal wash to clean out the peritoneal cavity.
    • Separate drainage for prevesical space and peritoneal cavity.
    • Administration of specific antibiotics to prevent sepsis.
    • Catheterization:
  • Malecot’s catheter is placed suprapubically.
  • Foley's catheter passed urethrally.
  • Complications:
    • Cystitis /and pyelonephritis.
    • Peritonitis.
    • Pelvic abscess.
    • Fistula formation (vesicovaginal or rectovesical).
    • Paralytic ileus.
    • Hemorrhage.
  • Prognosis: 100% mortality without surgery.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of resting tremor in his right hand, which improves with movement. He reports increasing slowness in daily activities and stiffness, particularly in the morning. He has had occasional falls due to unsteadiness while walking. Physical examination reveals a shuffling gait and cogwheel rigidity. All of the following are true statements regarding this condition except?

choices.text: A key pathological feature in the substantia nigra neurons is observed.
This condition can occur due to mitochondrial dysfunction.
Mutations in LRRK2 are the most common cause of autosomal dominant disease.
Homozygous mutation of glucocerebrosidase is an important risk factor for this condition.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Homozygous mutation of glucocerebrosidase is an important risk factor for this condition

Explanation:

  • The clinical vignette of resting tremors, early morning stiffness, unsteadiness, shuffling gait, and cogwheel rigidity is suggestive of Parkinson’s disease.
  • Homozygous mutations in glucocerebrosidase cause Gaucher’s disease, a lysosomal storage disorder.

 

Parkinson’s Disease (PD):

Autosomal dominant PD is SNCA, a gene that encodes α-synuclein. This protein is a major component of the Lewy body, which is the diagnostic hallmark of PD.

Autosomal recessive forms of PD, are caused by gene mutations that encode the proteins DJ-1, PINK1, and parkin (Option B).

Mutations in the gene encoding LRRK2 (leucine-rich repeat kinase 2) are the most common cause of autosomal dominant PD (Option C).

 

  • Clinical Features: Triad of tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia.
  • Morphology:
    • A characteristic gross finding in PD is pallor of the substantia nigra
    • Lewy bodies are usually single or multiple, cytoplasmic, eosinophilic, round to elongated inclusions.
      • They have a dense core surrounded by a pale halo.

Ultrastructurally, they are composed of fine filaments (composed of α-synuclein)

questions.text: As a part of neonatal resuscitation, you start chest compressions. For maximum effectiveness, what should be the depth of your compressions?

choices.text: ⅓ of AP diameter of chest
½ of AP diameter of chest
⅔ of AP diameter of chest
¼ of AP diameter of chest

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) ⅓ of AP diameter of chest

Explanation:

For neonatal resuscitation, chest compressions should be delivered at a depth of approximately one-third of the anterior-posterior diameter of the chest.

 

Site: In the middle, on the lower 1/3rd of the body of the sternum

Just below the line, joining the two nipples.

 

Depth: At least 1/3rd of the AP diameter of the chest

 

Technique:

  • 2 thumb technique (preferred) encircling the chest generates higher pressure, better perfusion, and lesser rescuers fatigability
  • 2 finger technique

questions.text: Which of the following medications is considered a first-line treatment for hirsutism in women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Combined oral contraceptives

 

Explanation: Combined oral contraceptives (COCs) are considered a first-line pharmacological treatment for hirsutism, especially in women with PCOS. They work by:

  • Suppressing ovarian androgen production
  • Increasing sex hormone-binding globulin, which reduces free testosterone
  • Decreasing 5α-reductase activity, limiting the conversion of testosterone to the more potent dihydrotestosterone

Management of Hirsutism:

Cause of Hirsutism

Specific Condition

Treatment



 

Ovarian androgens

Polycystic ovary syndrome
  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Antiandrogens drugs
  • Weight control
  • Metformin
  • Lifestyle changes
  • Laparoscopic ovarian drilling
  • Assisted reproductive technology

Luteoma of pregnancy/theca lutein cysts

Conservative management.
 

Adrenal androgens

Androgen-producing tumour

Remove the tumor.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (late onset) 21-hydroxylase deficiency

Glucocorticoid replacement and suppression.

Cushing syndrome

Varies as to cause.

Exogenous androgens

Hormonal drugs

Withdraw the offending drug.

Hair follicle sensitivity

Excessive conversion of DHT in hair follicle
  • Spironolactone
  • Cyproterone acetate
  • Flutamide
  • Depilatories
  • Electrolysis
  • Cosmetic treatments (waxing/shaving)

 

Spironolactone(Option A) is an androgen receptor blocker that can effectively reduce excess hair growth. However, it's typically used as a second-line treatment or in combination with other therapies.

 

Finasteride(Option B) is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor that can be used to treat hirsutism, but it's not a first-line treatment for women with PCOS. It's more commonly used in men for androgenetic alopecia and benign prostatic hyperplasia.

 

Metformin(Option D) is commonly used in the treatment of PCOS, particularly for insulin resistance and to regulate menstrual cycles, it's not a first-line treatment specifically for hirsutism.

questions.text: A 36 year old HIV positive patient presents with double vision, vomitting epsiodes with daily frontal headaches that dont respond to painkillers. Patient is not cooperative during physical examination due to headache. Fundus examination shows papilledema. Neuroimaging is performed. Which of the following is not correct about immediate management of this patient?

choices.text: Lumbar puncture for CSF CBNAAT for MTB

questions.solution:
Correct answer A:  Lumbar puncture for CSF CBNAAT for MTB

This immunocompromised patient is having ring enhanching lesions seen on MRI head. Lesions show “Target sign” with solid central nodule. First differential diagnosis in india TB meningitis. Due to raised ICP lumbar puncture cannot be performed in this patient as of now due to risk of brain herniation. Empirical ATT with steroids will be started along with measures to lower raised ICP. Double vision is seen this case due to 6th nerve palsy seen in raised ICP. 

Contraindications to Lumbar puncture

  1. Papilledema

  2. Focal neurologic deficit (esp. new onset)

  3. Midline shift or mass on CT/MRI

  4. Bleeding disorders / Anticoagulants

  5. Skin infection at site

  6. Uncontrolled seizures

  7. Signs of raised ICP with impending herniation

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with a history of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is being treated with Busulfan. She presents to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain and swelling, fatigue, and yellowing of the skin. Additionally, the patient reports experiencing episodes of seizures since starting busulfan therapy. Upon examination, the patient has hepatomegaly and jaundice. Liver function tests indicate elevated liver enzymes. Which of the following statements is incorrect for the next steps?

choices.text: The patient’s should be started on defibrotide as the symptoms are likely due to Budd-Chiari syndrome (Veno-Occlusive Disease)
Prompt administration of warfarin to reduce chances of another episode of VOD.
Patients should be started on antiepileptics such as phenytoin to prevent seizures.
Adjust the dose of busulfan based on plasma drug-level monitoring.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Prompt administration of warfarin to reduce chances of another episode of VOD.


Explanation:

The patient is a typical case of Budd-Chiari like Syndrome, a type of Veno Occlusive Disease (VOD) commonly seen in the patients on busulfan. Warfarin is an anticoagulant and is not used for the treatment of VOD. Therefore, this statement is incorrect.

Side effects of Busulfan includes:-

  • Bone marrow suppression (maximum risk)
  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Seizures
  • Budd-Chiari like syndrome
  • Tumor lysis syndrome

The patient’s should be started on defibrotide as the symptoms are likely due to Budd-Chiari syndrome (Veno-Occlusive Disease) (Option A):

The management of VOD focuses on use of defibrotide which is an antithrombotic agent as the treatment of choice.

 

Patients should be started on antiepileptics such as phenytoin to prevent seizures (Option C):

Patients on Busulfan, if experiencing episodes of seizures, are to be started on phenytoin, which is the frequently used anti-epileptic for patients on Busulfan. However, Phenytoin also induces the enzymes that metabolize busulfan, reducing its plasma concentration by about 20% thus reducing its side effects.

 

Adjust the dose of busulfan based on plasma drug-level monitoring (Option D):

 

Adjusting the dose of Busulfan based on plasma drug-level monitoring is frequently done to balance therapeutic efficacy and minimize toxicity, especially since Busulfan clearance can vary significantly among patients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of thyroid disease presents with bilateral eye bulging and difficulty closing her eyes. On examination, there is noticeable eye protrusion, eyelid swelling, and restricted extraocular movements. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of her eye condition?

choices.text: Extraocular muscles are the primary target of inflammation.
The earliest defective ocular movement seen in this patient is depression.
T-cells attack the orbital fibroblasts and adipocytes in the orbit.
Inflammation is primarily due to neutrophils.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) T-cells attack the orbital fibroblasts and adipocytes in the orbit.

 

Explanation:

  • This scenario is related to thyroid eye disease (Graves’ orbitopathy), where T-cells attack orbital fibroblasts and adipocytes.
  • This autoimmune response causes inflammation, increased fat formation, and swelling, leading to eye protrusion and eyelid swelling.
  • The extraocular muscles are affected secondarily.

Pathogenesis of Thyroid Eye Disease (Graves' Orbitopathy)

  • It involves an organ-specic autoimmune reaction in which anti-thyrotropin-receptor antibody reacts against thyroid gland cells and orbital broblasts.
  • Insulin-like growth factor 1 receptor (IGF-1R) and the thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor (TSHR) are upregulated in orbital and brow fat, leading to inflammation of extraocular muscles, interstitial tissues, orbital fat and lacrimal glands.
  • Osmotic imbibition of water (pleomorphic cellular infiltration (Option D ruled out) and increased secretion of glycosaminoglycans) and lipogenesis induced by broblasts and preadipocytes, which causes orbital fat enlargement.
  • Optic nerve may be compression (increased IOP).
  • Subsequent degeneration of muscle fibres results in restrictive myopathy and diplopia.
  • Primary Target: Orbital fibroblasts
  • Secondary Involvement: Extraocular muscles (Option A ruled out).
  • Optic nerve compression in thyroid ophthalmopathy is typically due to increased orbital volume (from inflammation and muscle swelling), not from vascular occlusion.
  • The increase in orbital contents can compress the optic nerve, leading to visual disturbances.

 

  • The earliest defective ocular movement seen in this patient is elevation. (Option B)

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with chronic abdominal pain, bloating, and alternating diarrhea and constipation. Following a diagnosis of Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS), which dietary approach is considered the most effective for managing her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Low FODMAP diet

Explanation:

  • A Low FODMAP diet in IBS patients involves restricting certain fermentable carbohydrates known as FODMAPs (fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols) that are poorly absorbed in the small intestine.
  • These FODMAPs can cause symptoms of IBS such as bloating, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and gas due to their fermentation by gut bacteria and osmotic effects in the intestine.

Low gluten diet (Option A): Advised in Celiac sprue.

Atkins diet (Option B) & Ketogenic diet (Option C): Followed for weight loss.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with an erection lasting over 6 hours and initial aspiration fails to resolve the condition. What is the next appropriate step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intracavernosal phenylephrine injection

 

Explanation:

  • Intracavernosal phenylephrine, a sympathomimetic drug, is the next step after aspiration fails.
  • It helps to induce detumescence by constricting blood vessels and reducing blood flow into the penis.

Oral phosphodiesterase inhibitors  (Option A) are used to treat erectile dysfunction but are not appropriate for the acute management of priapism.

Observation (Option B) may be appropriate in cases of non-ischemic priapism, but for ischemic priapism, active intervention is required.

Penile prosthesis placement (Option D) is considered a last resort for refractory cases that do not respond to other treatments. It is not the next immediate step after aspiration failure.

questions.text: Which BNS section denotes that consent given by an insane person is invalid?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) 28 BNS / IPC 90

 

Explanation:

The consent given by an insane or intoxicated person, who is unable to understand the nature and consequences of that to which he gives his consent is invalid ( 28 BNS / IPC 90 )

 

Provisions under the Act

BNS Section

Corresponding IPC Section

Any act done without intent to cause death or serious harm, but done with consent, is not considered an offense.

25 (Option A)

87

An act done in good faith with the consent of the person, for their benefit, is not an offense.

26 (Option B)

88

An act done in good faith for the benefit of a child under 12 years old or an insane person, with the consent of a guardian, is not an offense.

27

89

Consent is invalid if:

  • Given under fear or misconception
  • Given by an insane person

28 (Option C)

90

The exceptions under sections 25, 26, and 27 do not apply to acts that independently constitute offenses, or are intended or likely to cause harm to the person giving consent or on whose behalf consent is given.

29

91

Acts done in good faith without consent are permissible in the following situations:

  • During an emergency
  • When the person is incapable of giving consent
  • When there is no guardian to give consent

30 (Option D)

92

Acts causing slight harm are not considered offenses.

33

95

questions.text: A woman presents at 33 weeks of gestation and the umbilical artery doppler imaging shows the following finding. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Terminate the pregnancy at 34 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Immediate termination of pregnancy

 

Explanation:

  • The umbilical artery doppler depicts reversal of end diastolic flow as waves appearing below baseline which is seen in intrauterine growth restriction. As the period of gestation has exceeded 32 weeks , the pregnancy can be terminated.
  • In case of absent end diastolic flow, the waves just touch the baseline but dont appear below it. This suggest fetal compromise, hence the pregnancy is terminated by C Section if >34 weeks.
  • Reverse end diastolic flow suggests impending fetal death , hence the pregnancy is terminated by C section if >32 weeks.

 

Patterns  of end diastolic flow in umbilical artery :

questions.text: A researcher is studying the behavior of hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) and wants to understand the mechanisms that regulate their self-renewal during tissue repair. Which type of stem cell division increases the stem cell pool during tissue repair?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Symmetric division

 

Explanation:

Symmetric division results in both daughter cells retaining stem cell properties, thereby increasing the stem cell pool, which is crucial during tissue repair.
 

Pathway

Definition

Mechanisms / Factors

Signaling Pathways

Self-Renewal

Produces at least one daughter cell with stem cell properties

Symmetric and Asymmetric Division

Wnt, Notch, TGF-β

Differentiation

Produces specialized cell types

Transcription Factors, Microenvironmental Signals

Wnt, Notch, TGF-β

Both Pathways

Balance between self-renewal and differentiation to maintain stem cell pool and tissue function

Interplay of intrinsic and extrinsic factors

  

Stem cell types and their properties:

Stem Cell Type

Description

Example

Totipotent Stem Cells

Can generate the entire organism, including the placenta.

Single cell from the 8-cell embryo stage.

Pluripotent Stem Cells

Can generate the entire organism except the placenta.

Cells from the inner cell mass of the blastocyst.

Multipotent Stem Cells

Can form only one lineage of cells.

Hematopoietic stem cells that give rise to various blood cell types.

Steps in hematopoiesis:

Multipotent Stem Cell ➜ Progenitor Cell ➜ Precursor Cell ➜ Mature Cell
Mature Cell: Differentiated cell with decreased self-renewal and proliferation properties.

  • Hematopoietic Stem Cells: Convert to multipotent stem cells, giving rise to two progenitor types.
  • Memory B and T Cells are mature cells but have the ability to self-renew and proliferate.

 

 

Asymmetric division (Option A) – Maintains homeostasis by generating one stem cell and one differentiated cell, rather than expanding the pool.

Terminal differentiation (Option C) – Leads to fully specialized cells with no further division

Lateral inhibition (Option D) – A process in which a cell inhibits its neighboring cells from adopting the same fate, playing a role in cell differentiation rather than expanding the stem cell pool.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is experiencing severe allergic reactions after eating shellfish. Her doctor prescribes a medication to help manage these symptoms. Which histamine receptors are primarily involved in regulating the allergic response?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) H1 receptor

Explanation:

H1 receptors are primarily involved in regulating allergic responses, including smooth muscle contraction, increased vascular permeability, and stimulation of sensory nerve endings. 

Receptor

Functions

Locations

H1

(Option A)
  • Allergic responses
  • Smooth muscle contraction
  • Increased vascular permeability
  • Stimulation of sensory nerve endings.
  • Smooth muscle cells
  • Endothelial cells
  • Neurons
  • Immune cells

H2

(Option B)
  • Gastric acid secretion
  • Airway mucus production
  • Vascular permeability
  • Parietal cells in the stomach lining.

H3 (Option C)
  • Neurotransmitter release modulation
  • Central nervous system (CNS)

H4

(Option D)
  • Immune responses
  • Chemotaxis
  • Cytokine production
  • Mast cells
  • Eosinophils
  • T cells

questions.text: A 65-year-old bedridden patient presents with a stage III pressure sore on the sacrum. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management approach?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Application of hydrocolloid dressing

Explanation:

The management of pressure sores depends on the stage and severity of the wound.

For a stage III pressure sore, conservative management is typically the initial approach, with surgery reserved for more advanced cases or when conservative measures fail.

 

Conservative management includes:

1. Pressure relief: Repositioning the patient every 2-3 hours

2. Wound care: Cleaning and dressing the wound

3. Nutritional support: Ensuring adequate protein and calorie intake

4. Hydrocolloid dressings: These maintain a moist environment, promote autolytic debridement, and protect the wound

 

Surgical management is considered for:

1. Stage III and IV pressure sores that fail to heal with conservative measures

2. Exposed bone, tendon, or joint

3. Undermining, tunneling, or sinus tract formation

 

Surgical options include:

Immediate surgical debridement (Option A) is incorrect as it's too aggressive for initial management.

Negative pressure wound therapy (Option C) is typically used after debridement and is not the first-line treatment.

Flap reconstruction (Option D) is a surgical option reserved for more advanced cases or when conservative measures fail.
