questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a three-week history of progressively worsening temporal headaches, jaw pain, and visual disturbances. On examination, her right temporal artery appears swollen and tender to palpation. Which of the following statements regarding this condition are false?

choices.text: It is the most common cause of vasculitis in adults
It occurs as a result of a B cell-mediated immune response
It is associated with polymyalgia rheumatica

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It occurs as a result of a B cell-mediated immune response.

 

Explanation :

  • The clinical presentation of a 68-year-old woman with worsening temporal headaches (classical symptom), jaw pain (most specific symptom), visual disturbances (most dangerous complication), and tender and swollen right temporal artery points towards the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis.

Temporal arteritis/Giant cell arteritis:

  • Giant cell (temporal) arteritis involves large- to medium-sized arteries. (Option A ruled out)
  • Epidemiology: Most common type of vasculitis in adults (usually >50 years old) (Option B ruled out)
  • It is frequently associated with polymyalgia rheumatica. (Option D ruled out)
  • It is a T-cell-mediated immune response (Option C)
  • Biopsy findings: 
    • Giant cells
    • Granulomas
    • Fragmentation of internal elastic lamina
  • Special stain: Verhoeff-Van Gieson stain (to visualize elastic lamina)
  • Fragmentation of internal elastic lamina: Elastic lamina is mostly present everywhere but fragmented in some places.

questions.text: Which of the following biochemical reactions is not regulated by allosteric regulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Glucokinase in glycolysis

Explanation:

Glucokinase catalyzes the first step of glycolysis, converting glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. Unlike some other enzymes, glucokinase is primarily regulated by product inhibition (glucose-6-phosphate) rather than allosteric regulation.

 

  • Allosteric regulation is a mechanism where an enzyme's activity is modified by the binding of an effector molecule at a site other than the active site, known as the allosteric site.
  • Allosteric Site: A specific location on an enzyme distinct from the active site where effector molecules bind, inducing conformational changes that influence enzyme activity.
  • Effectors: Molecules that bind to the allosteric site and modify enzyme activity.
  • Conformational Changes: Binding of an effector to the allosteric site causes a conformational change in the enzyme, which can alter the enzyme's affinity for its substrate and modify the enzyme's catalytic efficiency.

 

Examples of Allosteric Regulation

Enzyme

Allosteric Inhibitor

Allosteric Activator

Notes

Phosphofructokinase (Option A)

ATP, citrate

AMP, F-2,6-P

Key regulatory enzyme in glycolysis

Aspartate transcarbamoylase (Option B)

CTP

ATP

Important in pyrimidine synthesis

Glycogen phosphorylase (Option C)

ATP, glucose-6-P

AMP

Regulates glycogen breakdown

Pyruvate kinase

ATP, alanine

F-1,6-BP

Regulates glycolysis

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents, who are concerned about the absence of his left testicle in the scrotum. On physical examination, the right testicle is palpable in the scrotum, but the left is not. All are true regarding this condition except?

choices.text: It can occur in association with hypospadias.
The most common site of arrest of descent is the inguinal canal.
It is very commonly associated with a well-defined hormonal disorder.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) It is very commonly associated with a well-defined hormonal disorder.

Explanation:

Cryptorchidism:

  • It is a complete or partial failure of the intra-abdominal testes to descend into the scrotal sac, associated with testicular dysfunction and an increased risk of testicular cancer.
  • It usually occurs as an isolated anomaly but may be accompanied by other genitourinary tract malformations, such as hypospadias. (Option A)
  • The normal descent of the testes occurs in two phases:
    • Transabdominal phase: Mediated by Mullerian inhibiting substance.
    • Inguinoscrotal phase: Mediated by the androgen-induced release of calcitonin-related gene peptide.
    • Any problem in any of these descents can lead to cryptorchidism.
  • Sites of arrest of descent:
    • Inguinal canal (most common). (Option B)
    • Abdomen (uncommon).
  • When the testis fails to descend into the scrotum, it is deprived of the temperature needed for spermatogenesis. As a result, sperm production does not occur, and the seminiferous tubules contain only Sertoli cells (Sertoli cell–only syndrome).
  • Leydig cells outside the tubules may appear prominent—not from true hypertrophy or hyperplasia, but due to the absence of germ cells—though this prominence is often mistakenly reported as Leydig cell hyperplasia. (Option D)

questions.text: A 35-year-old construction worker sustained a deep puncture wound on his foot while working at a site. He stepped on a rusty nail. He was immediately taken to the nearest clinic. He does not recall his last tetanus vaccination. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate action to prevent tetanus in this patient ?

choices.text: Clean the wound with soap and water and administer the tetanus toxoid (TT) vaccine.
Clean the wound thoroughly, administer tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG), and give a tetanus toxoid (TT) booster.
Administer a course of antibiotics and advise him to keep the wound clean.
Clean the wound thoroughly, provide a tetanus toxoid (TT) booster

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Clean the wound thoroughly, administer tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG), and give a tetanus toxoid (TT) booster.

Explanation:

For a high-risk wound in a person with an uncertain or incomplete immunization history (Category D), thorough wound cleaning, administration of tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG), and a tetanus toxoid booster are recommended to provide both immediate and long-term protection against tetanus.

Only wound care.

Only wound care. (Option C)

Wound Care + TT single dose. (Option A)

course.

Unclean wounds: All other wounds that don't fulfil the above criteria.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with a history of recurrent painful, pustular lesions on scalp which heals with scarring. She is healthy otherwise with no history of similar lesions. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test?

choices.text: The culture of extracted hair alone.
Culture of extracted hair with patient-collected hair sheddings.
Shave biopsy of scalp and culture of extracted hair.
Punch biopsy of scalp and culture of extracted hair.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Punch biopsy of scalp and culture of extracted hair

 

Explanation:

The patient presented with a history of recurrent painful, pustular lesions on the scalp which heal with scarring suggests the diagnosis of Folliculitis decalvans. A punch biopsy of the scalp and culture of extracted hair is the most appropriate investigation.

Folliculitis decalvans:

  • Folliculitis decalvans or tufted hair folliculitis is a progressive pattern of cicatricial alopecia of the scalp.
  • Its characteristic feature is the presence of multiple tufts of hair emerging from a single follicular opening also known as Doll’s hair appearance
  • The images below depict the scaring alopecia seen in Folliculitis decalvans.

 

  • Diagnosis is based on clinical and histological findings. Ideal biopsy tissue should contain clinical signs of scarring, no follicular ostia, and active inflammation (pustules, erythema, etc.).
  • Hence, a punch biopsy that extends into the subcutaneous fat is our preferred procedure for the pathologic evaluation of FD.
  • Oral antibiotics (Tetracyclines) are the mainstay treatment.

questions.text: A concerned mother brings her 2-year-old child, worried about the child's short stature. On examination, it is found that the child’s bone age matches the chronological age but the height falls more than 2 standard deviations below the average for the child's age. The child has no other developmental anomalies, and both parents are of short stature. What is the most likely cause of the short stature in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Familial short stature

 

Explanation:

 

Familial short stature: This is consistent with the child's height being below 2 SD, especially given that her parents are also short, suggesting genetic factors rather than a medical condition.

Familial short stature (FSS) is when a child's height is below average due to genetic factors, specifically the height of their parents.

  • Genetics: Short stature runs in the family.
  • Growth Pattern: Normal growth rate but consistently below the average height percentile.
  • Development: Normal development with no underlying health issues.
  • Final Height: Typically reaches a final height consistent with genetic potential but remains lower than average normal height.

Diagnosis: Based on family history and growth patterns, after ruling out other causes of short stature.

Growth hormone deficiency (Option B) & Cushing syndrome (Option D): These typically present with a significantly lower height percentile and delayed growth velocity, not usually seen with normal development and no other abnormalities.

 

Turner syndrome (Option C) This condition usually presents with specific physical features and typically becomes more apparent with delayed puberty, not commonly diagnosed in a 2-year-old with normal growth and development.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female is scheduled for an ERCP using the contrast mentioned below. Which type of contrast agent is it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Non-ionic Monomer

 

  • Iohexol is an iodine contrast agent that is classified as a Non-ionic monomer.
  • The commonly used iodine contrast agents are water soluble and are classified into ionic and non-ionic groups based on their osmolality and chemical structure.
  • The iodine particle ratio helps decide the osmolality of the drug, where high osmolar drugs pose a higher risk for kidney damage.

 

Iodine Particle Ratio
  • Ionic = 2 particles
  • Non-ionic = 1 particle
  • Monomer = 3 iodine
  • Dimer = 6 iodine

Intravenous and Intra-arterial

Commonly used for contrast in CECT (3D X-ray), Interventional Radiology, and X-rays like as in

  • Intravenous pyelogram

Mild reactions:

  • Hives (Urticaria)

Moderate to severe reactions:

  • Wheezing
  • Anaphylactoid reactions (Non-IgE mediated)
  • Also known as Contrast-Induced Acute Kidney Injury (AKI).
  • It is defined as an increase in serum creatinine by > 0.5 mg/dL or a > 25% rise from the baseline within 3 days of contrast administration, without any other clear cause.
  • Risk factors:
    • Patients with pre-existing kidney disease.
    • Pre-contrast eGFR < 60 mL/min/1.73 m² indicates higher risk.

Management:

Observation for mild reactions

Management:

  • Severe reactions: Requires epinephrine and advanced airway management as needed.

Management:

Intravenous hydration (e.g., normal saline)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a long history of heavy alcohol use presents with fatigue, jaundice, and abdominal distension. Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly, spider angiomas, and ascites. What is the most specific investigation to diagnose his condition?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient with newly diagnosed TB is prescribed a regimen as part of her treatment plan. The healthcare provider emphasizes the importance of monitoring for neurotoxicity as a potential adverse effect associated with this therapy. What dose of Vitamin B6 is given to prevent neurotoxicity with the use of this drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 10 mg/day

Explanation:

10mg of Vit B6 is given prophylactically to prevent neurotoxicity with the use of Isoniazid (INH) as part of the anti-tubercular drug regimen.

The side effects and uses of INH are given below

Side effects

Uses
  • Neurotoxicity
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Endocrine effects: INH induces CYP enzymes, potentially leading to gynaecomastia (in males) due to increased estrogen production.
  • Other effects: Lethargy, mild anemia (sideroblastic), arthralgia, and rashes are also associated with INH use.
  • First-line drug for the treatment of active TB infection
  • DOC for the treatment of latent TB infection

25-50 mg/day (Option A) is the prophylactic dose given in pregnancy and children.

100 mg/day (Option C) is the dose given for isoniazid toxicity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with severe pain in her right eye, worsened by eye movements, and reduced vision. On examination, proptosis and restricted ocular movements were observed. Ophthalmoscopy shows disc, macular edema, and choroidal folds. Which of the following B-scan ultrasonography findings is most indicative of this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) T sign

 

Explanation:

  • Given the clinical presentation of severe pain in the eye, proptosis, restricted ocular movements, reduced vision, disc, and macular edema, and the potential findings of choroidal folds, the diagnosis most consistent with these symptoms is posterior scleritis.
  • Thickening of the posterior sclera, retrobulbar thickening, and fluid surrounding the optic nerve creates a characteristic “T” sign in B-scan ultrasound.
    • In posterior scleritis, fluid accumulates in the sub-Tenon’s space due to inflammation.
    • On B-scan, this fluid tracks along the optic nerve sheath.
    • The horizontal line = scleral thickening + fluid
    • The vertical line = optic nerve
    • Together → form a “T-shaped” sign

 

Moth-Eaten Appearance (Option B): Seen in Retinoblastoma, characterized by intraocular calcifications, typically in children, not adults.

 

Sunray Sign (Option C): Seen in Choroidal Melanoma, due to radial vascularity, but this patient lacks an intraocular mass.

 

Kiss Sign (Option D): Seen in Total Retinal Detachment, where the detached retina folds inward, but this case has no retinal involvement.

questions.text: Gold standard investigation for steatorrhea is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: 72-hour faecal fat estimation

  • Steatorrhea is defined as stool fat excretion > 7% fat of dietary fat. Gold standard investigation for it is 72-hour faecal fat estimation.
  • Breath triolein test is a non-invasive screening method but not the gold standard; it’s less sensitive and rarely used in clinical practice.
  • PIVKA test measures abnormal prothrombin due to vitamin K deficiency, mainly used as a marker for liver cancer
  • Small intestinal mucosal biopsy is useful for identifying underlying mucosal diseases (like celiac disease) causing malabsorption, but it does not directly quantify fat loss.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset sharp chest pain and shortness of breath. On examination, he has decreased breath sounds on the left side, and chest X-ray confirms left-sided pneumothorax. The patient is scheduled for an urgent chest tube insertion under general anaesthesia. Which of the following inhaled anaesthetics is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Nitrous oxide

Explanation:

 

  • Nitrous oxide diffuses rapidly into air-filled spaces due to its low blood-gas solubility coefficient.
     
  • In a pneumothorax, this leads to expansion of the trapped air, worsening the condition and potentially leading to tension pneumothorax.
     
  • Therefore, it is absolutely contraindicated in conditions with air-containing spaces like:
     
    • Pneumothorax
       
    • Bowel obstruction
       
    • Middle ear surgeries
       
    • Intracranial air (post-neurosurgery)
       
    • Air embolism risk
       

Pneumothorax and inhaled anesthetics:

Effect on Air Spaces

Use in Pneumothorax

Nitrous oxide

Expands air-filled cavities

Contraindicated

Sevoflurane (Option A ruled out)

No significant effect

Safe

Isoflurane (Option B ruled out)

No significant effect

Safe

No significant effect

Safe

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a cause of early death in hanging?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Brain Infarction

 

Explanation:

Brain infarction is associated with delayed deaths rather than early deaths by hanging.

  • Early death typically results from immediate causes such as asphyxia, venous congestion, or reflex vagal inhibition.
  • Brain infarction is a later complication that may occur due to reduced blood flow or other factors following the hanging incident.

 

Death in Hanging

The usual period for death is 3–5 minutes and this can extend to 5–8 minutes of suspension leading to death.

  1. Immediate Death:
    • Occurs if cervical vertebrae are fractured.
    • This can happen if there is inhibition of the heart.
  2. Rapid Death:
    • Usually results from asphyxia.
  3. Least Rapid Death:
    • If coma is the cause, death occurs more slowly.


 

Causes of Death from Hanging

  1. Asphyxia: The constricting force of the ligature compresses the larynx and trachea, leading to asphyxia. (Option A ruled out)
  2. Venous Congestion: If the ligature is broad and soft, it can block the jugular veins, halting cerebral circulation. (Option C ruled out)
  3. Combined Asphyxia and Venous Congestion: This is the most common cause of death in hanging cases.
  4. Cerebral Anemia: Occurs when a thin cord is used as a ligature, reducing blood flow to the brain.
  5. Reflex Vagal Inhibition: This can result in sudden cardiac arrest. (Option D ruled out)
  6. Fracture/Dislocation of Cervical Vertebrae: Commonly seen in judicial hangings.

 

Delayed Deaths

Rarely, delayed deaths may result from:

  • Aspiration pneumonia
  • Edema of the lungs or larynx
  • Infections
  • Brain infarction (Option B)
  • Hypoxic encephalopathy
  • Brain abscess

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient is scheduled for an MRI to evaluate cognitive changes. Which of the following systems is specifically designed to provide shielding against radio frequency interference during the scan?
questions.solution:
• A Faraday cage is a conductive enclosure that shields its inner space from electromagnetic interference.
  • In MRI environments, this enclosure is typically constructed using wooden panels wrapped in copper wires, which provide effective radiofrequency (RF) shielding. This shielding helps minimize interference, which leads to imaging artifacts and ensures clearer and more accurate MRI results.
  • In the MRI facility, the cage is often visible through the special window glass separating the control room from the scanner area, further emphasizing its role in maintaining optimal imaging conditions.

Gradient Coils (Option A) are three sets, X, Y, and Z, used in the MRI imaging process to create intentional variations in the main magnetic field. These changes in the magnetic field enable the localisation of image slices.

Helmholtz coils (Option B) are a pair of circular coils arranged parallel to one another and function as Z gradient coils in MRI scanners.

Shim coils (Option C) are used to correct minor spatial discrepancies in the main static magnetic field and ensure optimal spatial uniformity, improving MRI image quality by reducing artifacts.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with an elevated PSA level of 12 ng/mL. A transrectal ultrasound-guided biopsy reveals a Gleason score of 9 (4 + 5). Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management approach for this patient?

choices.text: Active surveillance with regular PSA monitoring and repeat biopsies

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hormone therapy and possibly radiation

 

Explanation:

  • A Gleason score of 9 (4 + 5) indicates a very high-grade and aggressive prostate cancer, likely to spread rapidly.
  • The elevated PSA level and high Gleason score suggest advanced disease.
  • Hormone therapy, which reduces or blocks testosterone, is a key treatment for advanced prostate cancer.
  • Radiation therapy may also be considered to control local disease.

 

Gleason

Score

Grade

Components

Cancer

Grade

Description

6

3 + 3

Low-grade

Cells resemble healthy tissue; low likelihood of growth and spread.

7

3 + 4 or 4 + 3

Intermediate-grade

Cells show more variation; moderate risk of growth and spread.

8

4 + 4, 3 + 5, or 5 + 3

High-grade

Cells look very different; higher likelihood of rapid growth and spread.

9 or 10

4 + 5, 5 + 4, or 5 + 5

Very high-grade

Cells are highly aggressive; very likely to grow and spread quickly.

 

Management Strategy

Key Points

Active Surveillance (Option A ruled out)

For low-risk cases; regular monitoring

Radical Prostatectomy (Option B ruled out)

Surgery for localized cancer; potentially curative

Radiation Therapy

High-energy rays; external or brachytherapy

Hormone Therapy (Option C)

Reduces/block testosterone; for advanced/metastatic cases

Chemotherapy

Systemic drug treatment; for advanced/metastatic cases

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true regarding the POCSO Act?

choices.text: It is designed to protect female children under the age of 18 from sexual abuse
It also includes protection against digital sexual crimes and exploitation against children.
The Act was amended in 2019, making punishments stricter.
Special courts have been established to ensure the swift disposal of POCSO cases

questions.solution:
Answer: A) It is designed to protect female children under the age of 18 from sexual abuse.

 

Explanation: The POCSO Act is gender-neutral, and it protects all children, not just female children, under the age of 18 from sexual abuse.

 

Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act

Enacted in 2012, it is law in India designed to protect children under the age of 18 from sexual abuse, sexual harassment, and pornography.

 

Key Features of the POCSO Act:

  • Gender-neutral law (Option A)
  • It covers penetrative and non-penetrative assault, sexual harassment, and use of children for pornography
  • Burden of proof is on the accused, unlike many other criminal laws where the burden is on the prosecution
  • Mandatory reporting by adults and failure to do so can be punishable
  • Special courts for the trial of offenses to ensure a child-friendly environment
  • Identity of the victim is to be protected, and the proceedings are to be conducted in camera to prevent exposure

 

Recent Changes and Developments in the POCSO Act:

  • 2019 Amendment (Option C ruled out)
    • Stricter Punishments: Death penalty for aggravated sexual assault against children
    • The minimum punishment for penetrative sexual assault increased to 10 years, and for aggravated penetrative sexual assault increased to 20 years, with the possibility of life imprisonment or death in extreme cases.
  • Fast-track Courts to ensure swift disposal of POCSO cases, given the backlog of pending cases. (Option D ruled out)
  • Clarifications on ‘Touch’ and Sexual Intent:
    • The intent behind physical contact is crucial in determining whether it qualifies as an offense under POCSO.
  • Digital Crimes Against Children: (Option B ruled out)
    • Provisions related to the use of children for pornographic and online exploitation purposes have been emphasized with stricter penalties.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with a lack of pigmentation in their skin, hair, and eyes. The parents are concerned about the child's sensitivity to sunlight and the involuntary back-and-forth eye movements that the child exhibits. A significant decrease in melanin pigmentation is present. Which of the following enzymes is absent or deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
• Melanin is a pigment produced by cells called melanocytes, and it plays a critical role in determining the colour of our skin, hair, and eyes.
  • Tyrosinase catalyzes the first two steps in the conversion of the amino acid tyrosine to melanin.

 

Tyrosine → L-Dopa → Dopaquinone

 

  • Without enough functional tyrosinase, melanin production is reduced or completely absent, leading to the characteristic features of albinism.

 

Reaction

Enzyme

Tyrosine to DOPA

Tyrosine hydroxylase/ Tyrosinase

DOPA to Melanin

Non-enzyme catalyzed chemical reaction

Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) (Option A) is a liver enzyme that is released into the bloodstream when the liver is damaged.

Phenylalanine hydroxylase (Option C) is an enzyme that converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. A deficiency in this enzyme leads to phenylketonuria (PKU).

S-adenosylmethionine (Option D) required for:

  • Norepinephrine to Epinephrine:
    • Enzyme: Phenylethanolamine N-methyltransferase (PNMT).
  • Conversion of Homocysteine to Methionine:
    • Enzyme: Methionine synthase, using methylcobalamin as a cofactor.
  • Methylation of DNA:
    • SAM donates methyl groups to cytosine residues, affecting gene expression.
  • Synthesis of Creatine:
    • SAM is involved in the methylation of guanidinoacetate to form creatine.
  • Methylation of Neurotransmitters:
    • SAM is also involved in the methylation of other neurotransmitters, including serotonin to melatonin.
  • Lipid Metabolism:
    • Involved in the synthesis of phosphatidylcholine from phosphatidylethanolamine.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy has been brought to the emergency department with severe vomiting for the past 2 days. He appears dehydrated and lethargic.

Laboratory studies reveal:

pH: 7.52

pCO2: 38 mmHg

HCO3-: 32 mEq/L

Na+: 138 mEq/L
Cl-: 90 mEq/L
Urinary Chloride: 10 mEq/L

Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient's acid-base disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Initiate normal saline infusion

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with metabolic alkalosis (pH > 7.45, increased HCO3-) likely due to severe vomiting.
  • Also, the low urinary chloride (< 15 mEq/L) indicates a chloride-responsive metabolic alkalosis.
  • The most appropriate treatment is to initiate normal saline infusion.

Acid-Base Disorder

Primary Cause

Initial Treatment

Additional Considerations

Metabolic Acidosis

Excess HCO3- loss or H+ retention
  • Treat underlying cause
  • Fluid resuscitation (e.g., normal saline)
  • Start sodium bicarbonate (Option A)
  • Sodium bicarbonate rarely used, only if pH < 7.1 or life-threatening
  • Address electrolyte imbalances after initial resuscitation

Respiratory Acidosis

CO2 retention due to respiratory compromise
  • Assisted ventilation (NIV/IMV)
  • Treat underlying cause

For every 10 mmHg increase in pCO2, there is 4 mEq/L rise in HCO3- (metabolic compensation)

Metabolic Alkalosis (Chloride-Responsive)
  • HCl loss (e.g., vomiting)
  • Urinary chloride < 15 mEq/L
  • Volume repletion with normal saline
  • Most common type
  • Responds to fluid and chloride replacement

Metabolic Alkalosis (Chloride-Resistant)
  • Various endocrine disorders
  • Urinary chloride > 20 mEq/L
  • Treat underlying cause
  • May require specific treatments based on etiology (e.g., spironolactone for Liddle syndrome)
  • Acetazolamide
  • Does not respond to volume repletion alone
  • Requires targeted therapy based on specific diagnosis

Respiratory Alkalosis

CO2 washout due to hyperventilation
  • Treat underlying cause (e.g., fever, sepsis, asthma)
  • Adjust ventilator settings if over ventilated
  • Monitor for hypocalcemia (may cause tetany, seizures)
  • Metabolic compensation occurs over days

Provide oxygen therapy (Option B):

  • Oxygen therapy is not indicated in the treatment of metabolic alkalosis.
  • The patient's primary issue is related to fluid and electrolyte imbalances due to vomiting, not a respiratory or oxygenation problem.

Start acetazolamide (Option D):

  • Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that can be used to correct metabolic alkalosis by increasing renal bicarbonate excretion.
  • However, the immediate need is to address the underlying cause of the alkalosis, which in this case is due to chloride loss from vomiting.
  • Normal saline is usually the initial treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with vaginal discharge and itching for 1 week. Examination findings are provided below. Which of the following culture media cannot be used to identify the causative organism in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct naswer (C) Novy Nicolle McNeal medium

The given scenario, featuring vaginal discharge, itching, and a strawberry cervix, is consistent with a diagnosis of Trichomoniasis caused by Trichomonas vaginalis. This organism cannot be detected using Novy-MacNeal-Nicolle (NNN) medium, which is typically used for detecting Trypanosoma cruzi and Leishmania.

 

Diagnosis

  • Microscopy
    • Wet mount reveals,
      • The twitching (jerky or wobbling or rotatory) motility.
      • Pear shape with a single nucleus
      • 4 anterior flagella, 1 posterior flagella with an undulating membrane.
  • Permanent stain
    • Acridine orange, Papanicolaou and Giemsa stains can be used.
  • DFA (Direct fluorescent antibody)
    • More sensitive than wet mount
  • Culture
    • Most sensitive, gold standard investigation.
    • Following culture media can be used:
      • Lash cysteine hydrolysate serum
      • Diamond medium (Option A)
      • Trussell and Johnson medium (Option B)
      • Feinberg Whittington medium (Option D)
  • Serology
    • Tests like ELISA and Rapid immunochromatographic tests (lCTs) are also introduced.
  • Molecular method
    • DNA hybridisation, PCT, and nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT) are also available now.

questions.text: Which health management technique is used for creating a graphical representation of all events and activities required to complete a project enabling timely project completion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

 

Explanation:

  • Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT) is a type of quantitative health management method that involves creating a graphical representation (often an Arrow Diagram) of all events and activities required to complete a project.
  • It identifies the sequence of activities, calculates the time needed for each, and highlights critical activities that must be completed on time to ensure the overall project is finished as scheduled.

Systems Analysis Systems Analysis is a quantitative health management method focused on problem investigation, objective setting, and cost-effective evaluation of alternatives, without involving graphical or time-oriented project planning. (Option A)

Cost-effectiveness analysis is a type of quantitative health management method that evaluates the outcomes of different options in terms of costs and benefits to ensure (Option C)

Planning–Programming–Budgeting System (PPBS) is a type of quantitative health management method for allocating resources efficiently within an organisation. Still, it does not focus on graphical project management or critical path identification. (Option D)

questions.text: Following CT image is kept as a spotter in your final year exam viva. What is the marked structure?
questions.solution:
Marked cell located between floor of orbit and superior boundary of maxillary sinus is known as Haller cell - an example of anterior ethmoidal air cell.

 

Ethmoidal air cells:

Anterior Air cells:

Agger Nasi
  • Anterior most air cell of Ethmoid sinus
  • Site: Within the Lacrimal bone in the medial side of the Orbit
  • Relation: Anterolateral and inferior to the frontal recess

Haller cell
  • Infraorbital ethmoid air cell
  • Site: Present between floor of orbit and upper boundary of maxillary sinus

Bulla ethmoidalis
  • Most consistent and largest ethmoid air cell
  • Located just posterior to the Agger nasi

 

Posterior Air cells:

Onodi cell
  • Also known as spheno-ethmoidal air cell
  • Close proximity to Optic nerve and Internal carotid artery
  • Better appreciable on CT- axial view

 

Concha bullosa (Option A):

  • Pneumatization of middle turbinate
  • Most common deformity seen in nose, non-pathological
  • CT:


 

Pneumatized superior turbinate (Option C):

  • Occasionally the superior turbinate can undergo pneumatization
  • CT:

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with gradually worsening shortness of breath and fatigue. He has a history of tuberculosis treated 10 years ago. Physical examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) that rises paradoxically with inspiration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Constrictive pericarditis

Explanation:

  • The key words in question are Kussmaul sign- a paradoxical rise in JVP during inspiration and history of tuberculosis treatment indicates diagnosis as constrictive pericarditis. TB pericardial effusion is seen in untreated extrapulmonary TB and will have low voltage ECG.
  • Kussmaul sign is also seen in pulmonary embolism, RV infarction, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and advanced systolic heart failure.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with progressive conductive hearing loss. During a stapedectomy, the surgeon notes that the stapes footplate is fixed, but the annular ligament remains free. Which type of stapedial otosclerosis is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Biscuit type

Explanation:

The biscuit type of stapedial otosclerosis is characterized by fixation of the stapes footplate while the annular ligament remains free.

Types of otosclerosis:

  • Stapedial otosclerosis
  • Cochlear otosclerosis
  • Histologic otosclerosis

 

Stapedial otosclerosis causing stapes fixation and conductive deafness is the most common variety.

Sites of stapedial otosclerosis:

Type

Site of the lesion

Image

Anterior focus

Front of the oval window in an area called “fissula ante fenestram”

Most common type

Posterior focus (Option A ruled out)

Behind the oval window

Circumferential (Option B ruled out)

Around the margin of the stapes footplate

Biscuit type (Option C)

In the footplate the annular ligament is free

Obliterative type (Option D ruled out)

Completely obliterates the oval window niche

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about the Space of Retzius?

choices.text: Contains the vesical venous plexus draining into internal iliac veins.
Lateral boundary formed by bony pelvis and pelvic wall muscles.
Obliterated superior vesical arteries mark the lateral boundary.
The obturator neurovascular bundle enters the obturator canal to reach the thigh.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Obliterated superior vesical arteries mark the lateral boundary.

Explanation:

The obliterated superior vesical arteries define the medial boundary of the clinical paravesical space, not the lateral boundary of the retropubic space/ Space of Retzius.

Space of Retzius/ Prevesical Space:

  • It is a surgical area filled with loose connective tissue.
  • It is bounded anteriorly and laterally by the bony pelvis and pelvic wall muscles and ventrally by the anterior abdominal wall. Posteriorly, it accommodates the bladder and proximal urethra. (Option B)
  • Important neurovascular structures found here include the dorsal vein of the clitoris, draining into the vesical venous plexus and the inferior hypogastric plexus, supplying the bladder, urethra, and perineal structures. (Option A)
  • The obturator neurovascular bundle runs along the lateral pelvic walls before entering the obturator canal. (Option D)

questions.text: A 38-year-old chronic smoker presents with lower limb pain during walking for 2 weeks. Examination reveals an ankle-to-brachial systolic pressure ratio of 0.7. What is the correct interpretation of this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Intermittent claudication.

 

Explanation:

  • ABPI is measured supine by checking the systolic blood pressure in both upper and lower limbs (brachial, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis arteries).
    • The higher value from each limb is used to calculate the ABPI.
  • ABPI (Ankle brachial pressure index) or ABI (Ankle brachial index) here is 0.7 which indicates intermittent claudication in Buerger's disease.

ABI / ABPI = Systolic BP in the Ankle/ Systolic BP in the arm

 

Value

Interpretation

0.1 - 0.4

Critical limb ischemia (Option A)

0.5 - 0.9

Intermittent claudication (Option B)

1.0 - 1.2

Normal (Option C)

> 1.2

Calcified vessels (seen in patients with DM, End stage renal disease) (Option D)

questions.text:
Question:
A 22 y/o male with a history of worsening vision despite wearing rigid gas-permeable lenses now complains of increased visual distortion. O/E, his corneal topography shows progressive ectasia, and he is advised to consider treatment options to halt disease progression. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate to stabilize the condition and improve contact lens tolerance in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Corneal collagen cross-linking (CXL)

 

Explanation:

  • The patient has keratoconus showing progressive ectasia.
  • Corneal collagen cross-linking (CXL) with riboflavin is the most appropriate treatment for stabilizing keratoconus progression and improving contact lens tolerance in this patient.
  • It works by strengthening the corneal stroma through the cross-linking of collagen fibers, which helps to halt the progression of ectasia, thereby preserving vision and enhancing the effectiveness of contact lenses.

Treatment of Keratoconus

  • Spectacle Correction (Option A):
    • Effective in the early stages, but contact lenses are more beneficial.
    • Less effective in later stages due to irregular astigmatism.
  • Contact Lenses:
    • Rigid gas permeable lenses improve vision in early cases.
    • Specially designed scleral lenses (e.g., Rose-K) are useful in early to moderate cases.
  • Corneal Collagen Cross-Linking (CXL):
    • New treatment modality to slow disease progression.
    • Involves riboflavin (0.1%) eye drops and UVA radiation.
  • Keratoplasty (Option D)
  • Intracorneal Ring Segments (INTACS) (Option B):
    • Effective in early to moderate cases by flattening the cornea.
    • Less effective in halting progression.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with fatigue and pallor. Lab tests show hemoglobin of 9 g/dL and MCV of 68 fL. Peripheral smear reveals microcytic and hypochromic red blood cells. Her symptoms and laboratory findings are consistent with iron deficiency anemia. Which of the following statements regarding iron deficiency anemia (IDA) is correct?

choices.text: Serum ferritin is the gold standard investigation
Serum ferritin levels are not affected.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Decreased serum ferritin levels

Explanation:

  • Serum ferritin is a key marker used in diagnosing iron deficiency anemia.
  • In iron deficiency, ferritin levels are decreased because ferritin stores decrease as iron stores deplete. (Option A and D)
  • Serum ferritin levels below 30 ng/mL are generally considered indicative of depleted iron stores and are a reliable marker for iron deficiency.

Serum ferritin is the gold standard investigation (Option B): While serum ferritin is commonly used as a marker for iron stores, it is not considered the gold standard test for diagnosing iron deficiency. A bone marrow aspirate to directly assess iron stores is the gold standard for diagnosing iron deficiency.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with episodes of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness. Which of the following mechanisms is associated with the pathogenesis of this condition?

choices.text: Dilatation of the internal auditory artery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Defective absorption of endolymph

 

Explanation:

The given scenario is suggestive of Meniere’s disease, which is primarily associated with increased endolymph volume within the inner ear resulting from defective absorption/increased production of endolymph leading to increased endolymphatic pressure, which manifests as vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness.

 

Etiopathogenesis of Meniere’s disease:

Aetiology:

  • Increased Endolymph Volume (Option A)
  • Defective Absorption (Option B)
  • Vasomotor Disturbances: Sympathetic overactivity causing spasms in the internal auditory artery (Option C) may disrupt cochlear or vestibular function, leading to vertigo and hearing loss.
  • Allergy: Allergic reactions may cause the inner ear to produce excess endolymph. Many patients with Meniere’s disease have related allergies.
  • Sodium and Water Retention: Excess fluid retention can exacerbate endolymphatic hydrops, so reducing salt intake is recommended.
  • Hypothyroidism (Option D): A small percentage of cases are linked to hypothyroidism and can improve with thyroid replacement therapy.
  • Autoimmune and Viral Factors (Herpes family)

 

Pathology:

  • Meniere’s disease is characterised by distension of the endolymphatic system, particularly affecting the cochlear duct (scala media) and saccule, with possible involvement of the utricle and semicircular canals.
  • The cochlear duct can expand, pushing the Reissner's membrane into the scala vestibuli, potentially leading to the rupture of this membrane and mixing of perilymph with endolymph causing the classic symptoms.

questions.text: During a routine orthopaedic surgery, a 35-year-old female patient develops muscle rigidity, tachycardia, and elevated body temperature shortly after being administered halothane and succinylcholine. Which of the following actions should the anesthesiologist take first to manage this patient's condition?

choices.text: Stop halothane and succinylcholine, and hyperventilate with 100% oxygen.
Administer dantrolene and continue the surgery with halothane only.
Administer cold IV fluids with dantrolene.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Stop halothane and succinylcholine, and hyperventilate with 100% oxygen.

Explanation:

The priority in managing malignant hyperthermia is to immediately discontinue the triggering agents—halothane and succinylcholine—and then hyperventilate the patient with 100% oxygen. This helps to counteract hypoxia and stabilize the patient's condition.

 

Diagnosis of malignant hyperthermia

  • Best screening test- Creatine kinase test
  • Gold Standard Diagnostic test- Halothane-Caffeine Test

 

Treatment for malignant hyperthermia

  1. Discontinue volatile anaesthetics and succinylcholine immediately. Notify the surgeon and call for assistance.
  2. Hyperventilate the patient with 100% oxygen at a fresh flow rate of at least 10 L/min.
  3. Mix dantrolene sodium with sterile distilled water and administer 2.5 mg/kg intravenously as soon as possible. Repeat every 5 to 10 minutes until symptoms improve, with a maximum total dose of 10 mg/kg.
  4. Administer bicarbonate to address metabolic acidosis.
  5. Implement cooling measures, such as lavage, cooling blankets, and cold intravenous fluids.
  6. For severe hyperkalemia, administer dextrose (25–50 g IV) along with regular insulin (10–20 units IV for adults).
  7. Provide antiarrhythmic medications as necessary.
  8. Monitor end-tidal CO2 levels, electrolytes, blood gases, creatine kinase, serum myoglobin, core temperature, urinary output and colour, and coagulation status.

 

Administer dantrolene and bicarbonate immediately. (Option A): While dantrolene is critical, it should not be the first action. Stopping the triggers and ensuring oxygenation takes priority.

Administer dantrolene and continue the surgery with halothane only. (Option C): Continuing halothane use after administering dantrolene can worsen the condition.

Administer cold IV fluids with dantrolene. (Option D): While cold IV fluids and dantrolene are important for treatment, they should not be the first actions. Stopping the anesthetics and providing oxygen must come first for immediate stabilization.

questions.text: Which of the following does not come under the 4 A's of primary healthcare?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Accountability

Explanation:

Accountability, which relates to the responsibility of healthcare providers to deliver quality care, is not listed among the 4 A's of primary healthcare.

Health for All:

  • Proposed in 1977 by the World Health Assembly.
  • Attainment of the level of health by all individuals enabling them to lead socially and economically productive lives.
  • The 4 A's of primary healthcare are:

Accessibility: Healthcare services are available and reachable by all. (Option A)

Affordability: Healthcare services are economically viable for all (Option B)

Acceptability: Healthcare services are culturally and socially appropriate (Option D)

Availability: Appropriate ratio between the population of an administrative unit and the health facility

Principles of primary health care: 

  • Appropriate technology
  • Community participation
  • Equitable distribution
  • Inter-sectoral coordination

questions.text: A health camp was organized to conduct cervical cancer screening in pregnant females. Which of the following best explains this type of screening test?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: B) Multiphasic Screening

EXPLANATION:

Pap smear is a type of multiphasic screening that involves multiple tests, often starting with simple tests followed by more complex ones if initial results indicate a risk.

Types of screening tests:

 

1. Mass Screening (Option C)
  • All individuals screened irrespective of high risk.
  • Least efficient type of screening.

2. High-risk screening/ selective screening/ targeted screening

(Option A)
  • Only high-risk individuals are screened.
  • Most efficient form of screening.
  • E.g.:
    • Hypertension screening in the elderly.
    • TB screening in lower socio-economic population.
    • Breast cancer screening with a family history of breast cancer.

3. Multiphasic screening
  • Application of 2 or more screening tests in combination to a large number of people at one time to detect a single disease.
  • E.g., Health camps for cervical cancer: Questionnaire, Pap smear, Visual inspection.

4. Multipurpose screening (Option D)
  • Screen the population with more than one test done simultaneously to detect more than one disease
  • Screening blood tests of pregnant females (Hb, RA, HIV, VDRL, HbsAg)

5. Opportunistic screening or Case-finding
  • Screening conducted during routine healthcare visits for other reasons
  • Presumptive identification was not raised at the patient's request
  • E.g., Screen everyone above 30 for hypertension

questions.text: Which structure, located in the petrous part of the temporal bone, is responsible for transmitting the facial nerve (VII) and is commonly involved in pathological conditions such as acoustic neuroma affecting the cerebellopontine angle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Internal auditory canal

 

Explanation:

The internal auditory canal, located in the petrous part of the temporal bone, transmits both the facial nerve (VII) and the vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII). Pathological conditions like acoustic neuroma, which arises from the vestibular division of the vestibulocochlear nerve, commonly affect this canal and extend into the cerebellopontine angle, leading to symptoms involving both hearing and facial nerve function.

 

Anatomy of the Temporal Bone

Segments

1. Tympanic: Forms the external auditory canal (EAC).

2. Mastoid:

  • Contains the mastoid air cell system, which is essential for ventilation and drainage of the middle ear.
  • Includes the antrum, connected to the epitympanum, and surrounded by air cells.

3. Petrous:

  • Most medial part, containing the cochlea, vestibule, semicircular canals and internal auditory canal.
  • Houses the facial nerve (VII) and vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII).

4. Squamous: Flat part of the temporal bone that contributes to the lateral skull wall, providing attachment points for muscles and ligaments.


 

Important associated Structures
  • Cranial Nerves:
    • Facial nerve (VII) and Vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII) passes through the internal auditory canal
    • 9th, 10th, and 11th cranial nerves (glossopharyngeal, vagus, accessory) run through the jugular foramen.
  • Vascular Structures:
    • Jugular bulb and carotid artery run near the petrous portion, making the temporal bone a critical area for surgical considerations.
    • Labyrinthine artery passes through the internal auditory canal
    • Internal Jugular Veins make their way out of the cranium and terminate at the subclavian veins via jugular foramen.
  • Other structures: Internal auditory canal, cochlea, vestibule, semicircular canals, vestibular aqueduct, endolymphatic sac.

 

  • Tegmen tympani (Option A): The tegmen tympani forms the roof of the tympanic cavity but does not transmit the facial nerve. It separates the tympanic cavity from the middle cranial fossa.
  • Stylomastoid foramen (Option B): The stylomastoid foramen is the exit point for the facial nerve from the skull but is not involved in transmitting the facial nerve within the temporal bone.
  • Jugular foramen (Option D): The jugular foramen transmits the glossopharyngeal, vagus, and accessory nerves, but not the facial nerve.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents with redness, mild swelling, and foreign body sensation in the right eye for 2 days. On examination, no visual impairment is noted, and a diagnosis of acute conjunctivitis is made. Which of the following is not a common sign of conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D)

 

Explanation:

Ciliary congestion, also known as ciliary injection, is not a sign of conjunctivitis. It refers to deep, radial vessel congestion around the limbus, usually associated with intraocular conditions like iritis, keratitis, or acute glaucoma. The vessels here are part of the deeper structure of the eye, unlike the superficial vessels involved in conjunctivitis.

 

Symptoms and Signs of Conjunctivitis:

  • Hyperemia or redness of the conjunctiva (Option B)
  • Pain
  • Photophobia (rare, associated corneal involvement or iritis can be present)
  • Blepharospasm
  • Discharge (prominent feature)
  • Foreign body sensation
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage (Option C)
  • Chemosis or conjunctival edema (Option A)
  • Inflammatory reactions: Follicles (localized aggregation of lymphocytes), papillae (hyperplasia of the normal vascular system), granulomas
  • Pseudomembranes/True membranes

 

Feature

Conjunctival Congestion

Ciliary Congestion

Location of Congestion

Confined to the conjunctiva, often more marked in the fornices.

Involves the area around the corneal margin, known as the limbal region.

On moving conjunctiva

Congested vessels also move

Congested vessels do not move

Common Causes

Bacterial conjunctivitis, allergic conjunctivitis, viral conjunctivitis

Acute iridocyclitis, acute glaucoma, keratitis, corneal ulcer.

Image

questions.text: A 25-year-old male athlete presents to the emergency department after completing a high-intensity interval training session. He reports feeling extremely fatigued and experiencing muscle cramps. Blood tests indicate elevated levels of lactic acid. What is the net ATP yield when one molecule of muscle glycogen is converted to lactic acid during strenuous exercise?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C) 3 ATP

 

Explanation:

 

When one molecule of muscle glycogen undergoes anaerobic glycolysis (glycogen → lactate), the net ATP yield differs from glucose metabolism because glycogen breakdown bypasses the hexokinase step, which normally consumes ATP. Here’s a stepwise explanation:

  1. Glycogenolysis (Breakdown of Glycogen)

    • Glycogen phosphorylase removes glucose units from glycogen as glucose-1-phosphate (G1P).
    • Phosphoglucomutase converts G1P to glucose-6-phosphate (G6P).
    • Since G6P is directly obtained, it skips the hexokinase step (which normally consumes 1 ATP in glucose metabolism).

  2. Glycolysis (Conversion of Glucose-6-Phosphate to Pyruvate)

    • G6P enters glycolysis and follows the usual pathway.
    • Key ATP-related steps:
      • Energy investment: 1 ATP is used at the phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) step.
      • Energy generation: 4 ATP are produced from substrate-level phosphorylation.
      • Net ATP gain from glycolysis: 4 ATP (produced) - 1 ATP (used) = 3 ATP.

  3. Anaerobic Conditions (Conversion of Pyruvate to Lactate)

    • In anaerobic exercise (e.g., intense training), pyruvate is converted to lactate by lactate dehydrogenase (LDH).
    • This step does not produce or consume ATP; its main role is regenerating NAD⁺ for continued glycolysis.

ATP Yield Calculation from Muscle Glycogen Breakdown

Step Process ATP Change
Glycogenolysis Glycogen → Glucose-1-phosphate → Glucose-6-phosphate (no ATP used) +0 ATP
Glycolysis Glucose-6-phosphate → 2 Pyruvate +4 ATP
Energy Consumption ATP used in glycolysis (Phosphofructokinase-1 step) -1 ATP
Anaerobic Conversion 2 Pyruvate → 2 Lactate (No ATP change) 0 ATP
Net ATP Yield   3 ATP

Final Net ATP Yield:

  • Glycolysis from muscle glycogen produces 3 ATP (instead of 2 ATP when starting from free glucose) because the hexokinase step is bypassed.
  • No additional ATP is lost or gained during lactate formation.
  • Total ATP yield per glycogen molecule → 3 ATP.

1 ATP (Option A):

  • Incorrect because the actual ATP yield is higher. Even free glucose metabolism yields 2 ATP, and muscle glycogen yields 3 ATP due to bypassing hexokinase.

2 ATP (Option B):

  • Incorrect because this is the ATP yield when glucose (not glycogen) is used. Muscle glycogen metabolism produces one extra ATP by skipping the ATP-consuming hexokinase step.

4 ATP (Option D):

  • Incorrect because glycolysis does produce 4 ATP, but 1 ATP is consumed at the PFK-1 step, leading to a net gain of 3 ATP, not 4.

questions.text: A 62-year-old presents with sudden-onset left-sided weakness, primarily affecting the arm and face. On examination, he has difficulty with speech, displaying both expressive and receptive aphasia. He also shows left-sided facial drooping and an inability to move his left upper limb effectively. Sensation is relatively intact in his lower limb. Which artery is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Middle cerebral artery (MCA)

 

Explanation:

  • The MCA supplies the lateral aspects of the cerebral hemispheres, including the motor and sensory cortices controlling the face, upper limb, and speech areas (in the dominant hemisphere).
  • The patient's symptoms of weakness in the face and arm, combined with aphasia, strongly suggest an MCA stroke, as this artery is responsible for these regions.

An ACA stroke typically affects the lower limbs, and a PCA stroke would more likely present with visual field defects or sensory disturbances.

 

Artery Affected

Areas Involved

Clinical Manifestations

Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA)

(Option A)

Medial surface of the frontal and parietal lobes, corpus callosum
  • Contralateral weakness and sensory loss (lower limb > upper limb)
  • Urinary incontinence,
  • Personality changes (frontal lobe involvement),
  • Transcortical motor aphasia (dominant hemisphere)

Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)

(Option C)

Lateral surface of the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes, basal ganglia, internal capsule
  • Contralateral weakness and sensory loss (face and upper limb > lower limb)
  • Aphasia (dominant hemisphere),
  • Hemineglect (non-dominant hemisphere),
  • Homonymous hemianopia
  • Gaze preference towards the side of the lesion

Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA)

(Option B)

Occipital lobe, inferior part of temporal lobe, thalamus
  • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia,
  • Visual agnosia,
  • Thalamic pain syndrome,
  • Cortical blindness (if bilateral),
  • Memory deficits (if temporal lobe is involved)

questions.text: According to the two-cell two-gonadotropin theory, which hormone stimulates the conversion of androgens to estrogens in granulosa cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) FSH

Explanation:

According to the Two-cell Two-Gonadotropin Theory:

  • The ovary has two cellular components: Theca cells and Granulosa cells.
  • Theca cells → express receptors for LH.
  • Granulosa cells → express receptors for FSH.
  • LH stimulation of theca cells → production of androgens (testosterone, androstenedione).
  • FSH stimulation of granulosa cells→ conversion of these androgens to estrogens (estradiol, estrone) through the aromatase enzyme.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with floaters and gradual deterioration of vision. On examination, there is anterior vitritis with white snowball-like exudates and mild peripheral periphlebitis. No other relevant history or clinical findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intermediate uveitis

 

Explanation:

The presence of floaters, anterior vitritis, and white snowball-like exudates near the ora serrata with mild peripheral periphlebitis are characteristic of intermediate uveitis (pars planitis).

 

Intermediate Uveitis: Causes and Features

 

Definition:
Intermediate uveitis, also known as pars planitis, primarily affects the pars plana of the ciliary body and the peripheral choroid. It mostly occurs in children and young adults, with a higher incidence in females.

 

Causes

  • Etiology: Nonspecific inflammation with an unknown cause.
  • Onset: Insidious

 

Features

Common Features

Less Frequent Features

Floaters

Macular edema

Vision deterioration due to anterior vitreous opacities

Papillitis or disc oedema

Minimal aqueous flare with occasional keratic precipitates

Retrolenticular cyclitic membranes

Anterior Vitritis

Vitreous hemorrhage

White snowball-like exudates near the ora serrata

Tractional retinal detachment (rare)

Mild peripheral periphlebitis

  

  • Snowball-like exudates may coalesce into a "snowbank" appearance.
  • 80% of cases do not require treatment.
  • Chronic cases may require corticosteroids; however, there is poor response to therapy.
  • Immunosuppressants are reserved for severe cases unresponsive to steroids.

 

Differential Diagnosis

  • CMV Retinitis: Typically presents with focal retinochoroiditis rather than the diffuse features seen in intermediate uveitis. (Option A)
  • Peripheral toxocariasis
  • Tuberculosis: Typically causes anterior uveitis. (Option B)
  • Lyme Uveitis: May cause uveitis but typically presents with more acute dermatological symptoms, and the ocular findings are not as specific to intermediate uveitis as in this case. More commonly seen in the relapsing-remitting type. (Option D)
  • Sarcoidosis

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with galactorrhea (inappropriate milk secretion) and menstrual irregularities. After excluding other causes, the physician considers a potential pituitary dysfunction. Which hypothalamic hormone contributes to increased prolactin levels in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH)

Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH), in addition to its primary role in stimulating TSH release from the anterior pituitary, can also increase prolactin secretion. This dual effect may contribute to conditions like galactorrhea when prolactin levels are elevated.

 

  • The pituitary gland plays a pivotal role in regulating various endocrine functions, including growth, metabolism, and reproduction.
  • The activity of the pituitary gland is primarily governed by the hypothalamus, which releases specific hormones, either stimulating or inhibiting, that reach the pituitary.
  • The regulation of pituitary hormone secretion is a finely tuned process, primarily controlled by feedback mechanisms.
    • Negative feedback loops are the most common, where the end products of a hormone's action inhibit further hormone release to maintain homeostasis. An example is cortisol, which inhibits its own secretion through feedback on both the hypothalamus and pituitary.
    • Positive feedback, although less common, occurs in processes like childbirth, where oxytocin release enhances uterine contractions, leading to further oxytocin release.

A) Corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH): This hormone primarily stimulates the release of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) from the anterior pituitary, which in turn influences cortisol production by the adrenal glands. CRH does not directly affect prolactin levels.

 

B) Dopamine: This neurotransmitter serves as the primary inhibitor of prolactin secretion. Increased dopamine levels typically decrease prolactin release, the opposite of what is described in the scenario.

 

D) Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH): This hormone primarily regulates the release of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), which are involved in reproductive function. GnRH does not significantly influence prolactin secretion.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents with complaints of infertility and chronic lower abdominal pain for the past year. She mentions recent unintentional weight loss and occasional night sweats. Her menstrual cycles have been regular, but she has experienced heavier-than-usual periods over the past six months. Considering her symptoms and clinical history, the clinician suspects endometrial tuberculosis and decides to perform an endometrial biopsy for diagnosis.

Which is the best time to perform an endometrial biopsy to diagnose endometrial tuberculosis?

choices.text: Any time during the menstrual cycle

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) During the late premenstrual phase

Explanation:

The optimal time to perform an endometrial biopsy for diagnosing endometrial tuberculosis is during the late premenstrual phase of the menstrual cycle.

  • The tubercle is found in the basal layer of the endometrium and moves to the surface before menstruation. Following the shedding of the endometrium during menstruation, reinfection arises from the basal layer lesions or the fallopian tubes.

Layers affected: Endometrial tuberculosis typically affects the endometrial layer (60%) while sparing the myometrium.

Endometrial biopsy is done during the premenstrual period by D&C or hysteroscopy directed biopsy. Menstrual blood collected on the first day of menstruation (superficial layer is shed off) can also be used as a diagnostic sample because it may contain the bacilli responsible for the infection.

questions.text: A 16 year old adolescent presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of multiple papules, pustules, and comedones on her face and upper back. On examination, there are numerous open and closed comedones, inflamed papules, and a few pustules distributed primarily on her forehead, nose, and cheeks, with some involvement of the upper back. Which of the following statements regarding the characteristics of this condition is correct?

choices.text: It primarily affects individuals over the age of 40 and is also seen in adolescents.
It is not influenced by hormonal factors.
Genetic predisposition is not a contributing factor.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Comedones are the hallmark lesion.

 

Explanation:

  • The given clinical condition is diagnosed as Acne vulgaris, a chronic inflammatory skin condition associated with increased sebum production and the accumulation of dead skin cells within the follicles.
  • Comedones are clogged hair follicles (pores) that contain a mixture of oil (sebum) and dead skin cells. They are the hallmark lesions of acne vulgaris. They are non-inflammatory lesions and are of two types:

Open comedones (blackheads): These are follicles with a wider opening to the skin's surface and are not covered by the epidermis. When exposed to air, the keratin plug becomes oxidized and appears black.

Closed comedones (whiteheads): These are follicles with a narrower opening to the skin's surface and are covered by the epidermis. The accumulation of sebum and dead skin cells creates a white or flesh-coloured bump beneath the skin's surface.

It primarily affects individuals over the age of 40 and is also seen in adolescents (Option A): Acne vulgaris is typically seen in puberty and adolescence, not above the age of 40 years.

It is not influenced by hormonal factors (Option B): Hormonal fluctuations, particularly increased levels of androgens (such as testosterone), can stimulate sebaceous gland activity, leading to increased sebum production. They are often associated with hormonal conditions like polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH).

Genetic predisposition is not a contributing factor (Option D) : Genetic factors influence various aspects of acne development, including sebum production, follicular hyperkeratinization, and inflammatory responses. Thus, Genetic predisposition is a contributing factor to the development of acne vulgaris.

questions.text: In the His bundle electrogram (HBE), what does the H wave denote?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Depolarization of the His bundle

 

Explanation:
H wave in His bundle electrogram represents the depolarization of the His bundle

His Bundle Electrogram (HBE):

  • Invasive ECG procedure
  • A catheter containing an electrode at its tip is inserted through an arm vein into the right atrium close to the tricuspid valve. The electrode records the HBE.

 

 

Waveforms in the His Bundle Electrogram
 

A Wave

(Option A)

The A wave represents atrial depolarization.
 

H Wave

(Option C)

The H wave represents depolarization of the His bundle’s upper part.
 

V Wave:

(Option B)

The V wave represents ventricular depolarization.
 

Intervals in the His Bundle Electrogram
 

P-A Interval
  • The PA interval is the time from the onset of the P wave on the surface ECG to the onset of the A wave on the His bundle electrogram.
  • The PA interval typically ranges from 25 to 55 milliseconds.
 

A-H Interval
  • The A-H interval is the time between the onset of the A wave and the onset of the H wave.
  • Typically ranges from 50 to 120 milliseconds.
  • This interval represents conduction time through the AV node. A prolonged A-H interval suggests AV nodal conduction delay.
 

H-V Interval
  • Typically ranges from 35 to 55 milliseconds.
  • This interval represents conduction time through the His-Purkinje system. A prolonged H-V interval suggests an infranodal conduction delay or block.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male with a history of hyperlipidemia is being managed on a lipid-lowering therapy regimen. His current medications include atorvastatin for cholesterol management. During a follow-up visit, the patient's lipid profile indicates the need for additional triglyceride lowering, and the clinician considers adding a fibrate to his treatment plan. Which of the following fibrate drugs must be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Gemfibrozil

Explanation:

  • Gemfibrozil is a fibrate that significantly increases the risk of myopathy and rhabdomyolysis when combined with statins like atorvastatin. This is due to its strong inhibitory effect on the CYP2C8 and CYP3A4 enzymes, which are involved in the metabolism of many statins. As a result, it increases the plasma concentration of statins, leading to an increased risk of muscle toxicity.
  • Fibrates Mechanism: Activate peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPAR-α).

 

Fenofibrate (Option A): Most suitable fibrate for combining with statins because it minimally affects statin metabolism as it has no CYP action (less risk of myopathy).

Clofibrate (Option B): Clofibrate is an older fibrate associated with an increased risk of gallstone formation.

Bezafibrate (Option C): A second-generation fibric acid derivative with the least risk of myopathy.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male is on mechanical ventilation for acute hypoxemic respiratory failure (Type 1). His latest ABG shows:
pH: 7.43, PaCO₂: 38 mmHg, PaO₂: 54 mmHg, HCO₃⁻: 24 mEq/L.
Which of the following changes should be made to improve his oxygenation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Increase Fio2

The patient has Type 1 respiratory failure (low PaO₂ with normal PaCO₂), indicating a pure oxygenation problem.
Increasing FiO₂ is the most direct and effective way to raise PaO₂.It is alos the lastest and simplest way to improve oxygenation. It provides immediate increase in alveolar oxygen concentration and thus raises PaO₂ quickly. Always titrate FiO₂ up to 60% (0.6) before increasing PEEP.
Increasing tidal volume (A) or minute ventilation (D) would reduce CO₂, not help oxygenation.
Decreasing RR (C) would worsen oxygenation by lowering minute ventilation and overall alveolar exposure to oxygen.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman with a history of moderate alcohol use undergoes general anesthesia for an emergency appendectomy. The anesthesiologist uses halothane for induction and maintenance. Two weeks after the surgery, the patient presents with fatigue, nausea, jaundice, and tender hepatomegaly. Laboratory tests reveal the following:


	AST (Aspartate Aminotransferase): 850 U/L (normal range: 5-40 U/L)
	ALT (Alanine Aminotransferase): 920 U/L (normal range: 7-56 U/L)
	Total Bilirubin: 4.8 mg/dL (normal range: 0.1-1.2 mg/dL)
	Direct Bilirubin: 3.2 mg/dL (normal range: 0.0-0.3 mg/dL)


Which of the following best explains the patient's condition?

choices.text: Alcohol-induced liver failure precipitating due to surgical stress

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Immune-mediated hepatotoxicity of halothane

Explanation:
The patient's presentation is consistent with halothane-induced hepatitis, also known as Type-2 halothane hepatotoxicity. This is an immune-mediated reaction that typically occurs 1-2 weeks after exposure to halothane, especially in patients with previous exposure or risk factors such as moderate alcohol use.

Halothane

Category

Details

Chemical Properties

- Clear, heavy, colorless liquid

- Sweet, non-irritating odor, photosensitive (stored in an amber bottle with thymol preservative)

- Structure of an alkane

- Highly soluble in blood and tissues, hence can cause delayed recovery

Systemic Effects

- Cardiovascular: Myocardial depression, sensitization to catecholamines

- Respiratory: Respiratory depression

- Central Nervous System: General anesthesia, increased cerebral blood flow

Uses

- Induction and maintenance of general anesthesia

- Less commonly used now due to side effect profile

- Still used in some resource-limited settings

Side Effects

- Type 1 Hepatotoxicity: Mild, self-limiting liver injury (20-30% of patients)

- Type 2 Hepatotoxicity (Halothane Hepatitis): Severe, potentially fatal (1 in 35,000 after single exposure)

- Cardiorespiratory instability

- Arrhythmias, especially in children

- Malignant hyperthermia (rare)

Metabolism

- 20-45% metabolized in the liver

- Produces trifluoroacetyl (TFA) protein adducts which are immunogenic and are responsible for causing halothane hepatitis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a 10-year history of poorly controlled hypertension visits your clinic for follow-up. Her blood pressure is 158/96 mmHg, despite being on lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Her serum creatinine and potassium levels are within normal limits. Which calcium channel blockers would be the most appropriate addition to her long-term blood pressure control treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
Amlodipine is a long-acting dihydropyridine CCB, and it would be an appropriate choice to achieve better blood pressure control in the long term. It can be used as an add-on therapy with other antihypertensive agents, and its once-daily dosing improves patient compliance.

Mechanism of action of CCB (Dihydropyridines):

It blocks the entry of calcium ions through the L-type calcium channels in vascular smooth muscle cells, causing vasodilation and a reduction in peripheral vascular resistance.

 

Drug

Use

Rationale for Choice

Nifedipine (Option A) Short-acting

Primarily used for angina pectoris

Not recommended for long-term hypertension management due to its short duration of action and potential for reflex tachycardia.

Nicardipine (Option B) Short-acting

Commonly used in the management of hypertensive emergencies and perioperative hypertension or severe hypertension in the intensive care unit.

The short duration of action makes it less suitable for long-term hypertension management.

Clevidipine (Option C) Ultra-short-acting

Very short half-life makes it unsuitable for long-term hypertension management.

Amlodipine (Option D) Long-acting.

Recommended as a first-line or add-on therapy for the long-term management of hypertension

Preferred choice due to its long duration of action (up to 24 hours), once-daily dosing, and effectiveness in lowering blood pressure with good tolerability.
